Reviews.Header: Only if I knew this beforehand
Reviews.Pros: 1. People are generally nice, minimal/no office politics 2. Everyone is willing to share and offer help when necessary
Reviews.Cons: 1. Brief hierarchy of the company: Team Assistant (TA); Associate; Senior Associate; So on and so forth. If you just graduate from NUS/NTU/SMU, the entry level position offered to you will be Associate. If you're from any other local/private unis in SG, the entry level position the company deem suited for you is TA. So you may graduate the same year as your friend but they may be your superior because of your school:) These are applicable for fresh grads and majority of the teams only. TLDR, as a TA, you're basically everybody's assistant. You take instructions from anyone above your "rank" 2. Your day end at 7PM, so naturally you will miss your usual dinner time with your family and friends taking into consideration the travel time. (Timing can never match with your friends unless they starve and wait for you) 3. OT is norm and not paid (you feel elated when you're able to get out of office on time and still see bright sky lol. dont try to plan anything outside of work cause tasks are unpredictable and you may be given a task at 630PM and they expect you to complete asap) 4. Managers check in with you time to time and after sharing your concerns, work are still given to you (mgrs check for the sake of checking, they also need to report mah) 5. People are still working on leave/after office hours. Receiving messages and emails at 12AM? norm 6. If you speak chinese a) awesome cause you can 'blend" in easier and mgrs are generally glad to hear that you speak their mother tongue language b)boo cause you need to help your non-chinese speaking teammates (not their fault btw) with their work AKA translation. ppl from other teams will prefer to seek help from you than your teammate since they can communicate better with you in their language 7. No clear career progression, job scope not defined (always doing work with no background given) 8. Turnover rate high. around half of my teammates has left after staying for less than 6 months or before their 3 months probation. The burnout is real:) 9. Work is extremely manual. Time spent on Crtl C + Crtl V takes up your whole day, thats why the company needs TA 10. The only time you get to interact with your teammates is lunch time/ team bonding session (usually held after work but will still attend cause FOMO)

Reviews.Pros: + People are collaborative and it's easy to get help from someone on a different team + Working with similarly-aged peers
Reviews.Cons: 1) Lack of inspiring leadership from middle to senior management. - Management are usually parachuted from other departments without relevant experience (except working for the company). -Authoritarian leadership that does not allow room for differing opinions. Many managers have no choice but to execute decisions of senior management. - Decisions are often made in a knee-jerk manner, makes you wonder if the Management has any long term vision. E.g. Birthday leave was retracted less than 1 year after roll out; the direction for employees to book a seat via internal app was reversed less than 1 month after roll out. - Lack of trust for employees. It wasn't enough to enforce 5 days work from office, this was followed with an attendance tracking system to monitor time in office. 2) Elitism. Significantly different pay for the same role, depending on whether you are from local or private uni, or the honours class you graduated with. Recruiters ask for education transcripts from 'O' levels to university to benchmark you. 3) Slave driving culture. You don't get rewarded for volunteering to take on additional scopes but get a below-average performance grade instead. 4) Cost cutting is now the ultimate priority and done at all expense, including that of the welfare of employees. Welfare and benefits have been severely cut.

Reviews.Pros: + good to have a big name on your resume

Reviews.Header: On a downhill since start of 2022
Reviews.Pros: -colleagues are nice and approachable. -located at one north, quite nice office environment. -pantry (albeit has dropped in size and quality)
Reviews.Cons: -MANDATORY WORK FROM OFFICE 100% EVERYDAY -Attendance tracking (as of 14 Nov) to make sure employees are monitored to the minute. Official stance is attendance won't affect performance and is just to provide managers with "visibility" on employees working arrangement. But many can see the BS behind this. Shopee used to have attendance tracking in 2018 and has now reverted to this primitive method. What are we? Blue-collared workers stamping a time sheet? -Upper management changing workplace arrangements on a whim. Hot desk system was implemented and significant resources were poured into developing an app for booking tables. Then suddenly came the announcement to go back to 5 day full WFO. Everyone was working fine and delivering their deliverables, why make this useless change? - Birthday leave abruptly removed in first half of 2022. - many small things will be routed to senior management for approval. I'm pretty sure precious dollars are wasted if directors and whatnot have to manually screen through every application.

Reviews.Header: Sales Leadership have no idea what they're doing
Reviews.Pros: Great culture, great product, wonderful and lovely environment. Was actually looking forward to going to the office every other day. Really lovely people all around to work with
Reviews.Cons: Sales leadership team are totally clueless about what's happening on the ground. Too many internal politics happening with the higher ups in different geo locations. Every Aug - Dec there will usually be a huge chop in various depts just like The Purge. Job stability isn't there. A shame because this is a really great company to work for.

Reviews.Pros: Great company for Benefits such as flex plan or health plan.
Reviews.Cons: Too political. The department of Customer Success is managed by a senior leadership whom prefers to promote people based on their tenure rather than the expertise they have built over time throughout their different experiences externally. There are also persistent tensions and rumours that are taken into account by management when they have to do performance reviews, and cold hard facts such as performance based on numbers is massively overlooked. People are afraid of speaking up and when they do with proofs of what they say, they don’t get help or actions taken. Worst professional experience so far.

Reviews.Header: Great Company with Bad Middle Manager
Reviews.Pros: - Truly care for the employee. Put in lots of effort for employee - End of year closure - Given RSU & budget for WFH setup during covid period - have ERGs, and mentorship groups - got to enjoy various exciting belonging group and activities: pool games, maker club, etc. before Covid - Vibrant office & ergonomic 'auto-desk' - Lots of horizontal jobs around
Reviews.Cons: - Middle manager have too much control over individual promotion, growth, exposure,etc. If you get a good manager it is heaven, but once you got the bad one, it is absolute hell. And mind you there are some bad apples around. - System is old, outdated, lots of data integrity issue and all in silos. The company will need lots lots of effort & time to revamp all of this. - Low salary and very difficult to get increment. Small % increment even if there is any. - HR is useless. There was an ex colleague who had sexual misconduct issue, HR cant do anything and asked her to still talk to the perpetrator, so she needs to quit. - No psychological safety. Even GLINTS employee survey is just a way to bully the individual - Getting a promotion / job progression is very difficult and some even get same or lower pay. Summary: if you feel you manager is great, join this company and ask for higher pay. If you sense the manager is bad, run away.

Reviews.Pros: Sorry to say that there is no pros
Reviews.Cons: A lot of people is leaving and it is still on-going. Not recommended for new hire, as you know, there are so many people leaving in such a short time, where most of the time knowledge transfer will be carried out in a short time and you will need to become expert just through knowledge transfer. Poor planning, there is no ramping up for new hire. There is no plan ahead for resources, where people just left and lost all the knowledge. New hire will have hard time to trace the history and pick up. Module is under one people responsible which is very dangerous. If that module owner happens to resign, the knowledge just gone. A lot of more than 10 years working in this company leaving one by one. The foundation of this company is shaking.

Reviews.Pros: If one takes charge of their career and is confident enough to stand up for the right vs wrong, you will have better results. You have the freedom to speak if you can speak. Work culture is in such a way that it helps those who take interest in their progression and wouldn't for those who won't.
Reviews.Cons: Mid-level managers are a blunder, incompetent, complacent, resistant to change and have no management experience. They are mostly promoted because they have been in the company for a long time. The company is failing to train the mid-level managers and tell them what is expected of them. Salary is way lower than average in the industry. HR has gone down in terms of their arrogant behaviour and treats interviewees in a more humane manner now. This could be because of the dramatic ongoing attrition. Female employees in the company are far less compared to males. There is some level of gender bias, and discrimination, especially seen among long served employees. HR offer far low salary to female employees than the male with the same skillset and experience. So, bias is top-down and starts with HR itself.

Reviews.Header: So many re-org in short period

Processes alignments are a mess and even in same company and same department, different projects using different tool chains. Uncertainty for many roles especially for middle managers due to many re-org

Reviews.Pros: Direct managers and colleagues are kind and helpful people. Beautiful workplace with bistro, canteen, huge gym, yoga room, bbq pits. Do my work, no complains, go home. No OT (only if you do work non-stop)
Reviews.Cons: Higher up (some) toxic manger/boss. Does not listen to reason, shouts and increases voice in public to shame you and demeans staff / no respect. Embarrasses staffs in public, asks staffs to "don't talk back" everytime we try to explain something, micromanages staff, constantly increases our workload without asking if our plates are full, hence everyone doing 2-3 person work. (Here, she will tell us that everyone is busy too) Shut us down when we try to tell her our concerns. can't complain to HR because she will mark us if she finds out from them. Asks us to talk to her directly if has any complains, but we end up get scolding instead. No one want to talk to her anymore. No understanding, no empathy. Treats her staff like trash and animals, but treats those higher ranking staff like gods. Overall toxic department. higherups loves her, low ranking staffs can only suck it up. Entire department will have serious mental health issues sooner or later.

No work life balance if clients only allow deployment after office hours or weekend Pay not as attractive as the competitive companies, though there are adjustment to the remuneration package As the vendor of another organization, there are times that customers are rude and can even boycott you from projects.

Reviews.Header: Good starting place, please leave after a year.
Reviews.Pros: Good if you can't find a job or new to IT. Less rigid than government. WFH and culture is project director dependent.
Reviews.Cons: No food in canteen, no food nearby too. No clear protocols and documentation. No trainings and upskilling. You will be stuck here if you can't upskill on your free time.

Reviews.Pros: - Nice superiors who provide opportunities/exposures if you are proactive, willing to learn and independent enough with a can-do attitude - Not an environment with politics - Company made adjustment to base pay according to market rates
Reviews.Cons: - Overlap in responsibilities - May have difficult/uncooperative colleagues due to grey areas in terms of work scope - May be overloaded with work if you are the type who are willing to take on tasks out of your main scope

Reviews.Header: Good initiatives in providing work life balance, could have better benefits for employees
Reviews.Pros: The company has implemented good initiatives in improving employee benefits and work-life balance since the easing of COVID-19 restrictions. Employee benefits are relatively ok, with a group medical plan as well as Singtel staff discount for mobile plans.
Reviews.Cons: Although the company provides options for more work-life balance, some project team leads are advocating for more OTs and require employees to stay past normal working hours for good performance bonus reviews. (To them staying in the office longer = good performance??) There is also no compensation for OT. When project deadlines are near, employees are required to sacrifice off days, or personal time with no additional compensation. The only compensation is off in-lieu days, where they give back the day they took your weekend. Working on-site in the vendor office has no fixed working space, getting pushed around by vendor staff.

Reviews.Header: Great company to work in, especially for entry-level or mid-career switches.

Reviews.Cons: Compensation even though progresses well for good performers, can be made more competitive to retain more staff.

Reviews.Pros: The graduate program offers many certifications with no bond. Good for experience and upskilling.

Reviews.Pros: Many benefits related to insurance, internet and flexi bonus. Very professional and friendly team. Can request access to many training and courses related to job.
Reviews.Cons: No benefits extended to contract employees. This one thing demotivated contract employees to work hard. Its best to come to NCS as direct hire.

Reviews.Pros: After the new CEO, I can sense the leadership trying their best to make connection with us on the fields, very different when it was led by previous CEO.
Reviews.Cons: Pay always below market standard, while the works always above and beyond the market. During severe covid pandemic, Director asked us to come to office instead of working remotely. Reviews.Pros: - No office politics - A bunch of good collogues
Reviews.Cons: - Headcount planning went wrong: They mass-hired many people for the past year and start firing people now. People were asked to leave due to poor performance, but KPIs were not given to us at the beginning till now; they just gave a funny reason for firing people. "You" could have said the company is not doing well; thus layoffs are needed. Please do not give invalid reasons to fire people; this is outrageous. - There need to be transparent conversations between leaders and employees. The management should be more upfront with all the employees about company performance. - Leaders only focus on gaining credits. Despite verbally stressing their concerns for all employees' professional development, the leaders did nothing. For example, there is no monthly and quarterly performance review from the direct reporting managers. - The job scope is manageable: Many experienced HR professionals have been hired to perform simple job scopes, which junior employees can accomplish.

Reviews.Pros: Culture is spot on, room to grow, great guidances.

Reviews.Pros: In my assessment, the CEO and executives demonstrates a willingness to actively engage with their employees and foster transparency in their efforts to incorporate employee feedback. Notably, the company's town hall meetings offer a platform for candid inquiry and open dialogue. Additionally, Grab displays a commendable level of flexibility and responsiveness to employee needs and requests, with a clear emphasis on prioritizing employee well-being, including mental health. Especially, my team culture fostered a positive atmosphere in which employees are kind and considerate, expressing appreciation and offering constructive feedback to help others grow without causing negative feelings. Such behavior contributes to a supportive and respectful work environment that values employee development and well-being.
Reviews.Cons: The job could be demanding and potentially stressful, especially when balancing additional responsibilities on top of one's own tasks. It's important to take a proactive approach to demonstrate one's skills and make oneself visible to senior management to advance and gain recognition within the organization. The workload and project impact can vary among teams, contributing to the level of stress experienced in the role. Despite these challenges, the company does try to prioritize employee well-being.

Reviews.Header: Comprehensive Review of a SWE in Singapore
Reviews.Pros: - Above average compensation, - Smart colleagues! It feels awesome to collaborate and be surrounded by some of the brightest software engineers around, - Great benefits (amazing pantry, free lunch everyday, lots of company swag all year round, etc.) - and contrary to what many reviews here say... Pretty good work life balance! However, do note that this is largely helped by the fact that we're based in Singapore and thus exist in the same timezone as Beijing, so international meetings don't happen at odd hours for us compared to offices in London and Bay Area, for instance.
Reviews.Cons: - Less annual leaves than my previous company (but with the ability to carry forward unlimited leaves), - Slower career growth for non-China based employees (according to my co-workers) - and the occasional language barriers when dealing with international teams (which honestly isn't a huge deal breaker because everyone can speak English to some degree anyway)

Reviews.Header: Toxic culture, incompetent team leaders, Top-down management, avoid Chinese Company!
Reviews.Pros: 1. You get to work with young and talented local professionals; 2. Chances to take more responsibilities and learn from the job itself if you do not mind no work-life balance.
Reviews.Cons: Where do i begin? My list goes on... 1. Horrible talent management, they copy western companies' OKR and 360 degree performance review system, but TikTok leaders manipulated it in a way that you have to please your leader huge in order to get a good bonus as your 360 rating determines how much your bonus will be. That of course leads to a very top-down Chinese imperial management style. 2. Salary. HRBP and the team leads will try to negotiate so hard with you on your salary by leveraging the name TikTok which many believes it's the next Meta, but let's be honest, how far can TikTok go if they have a top-down management culture and bring in talents who later realise they're all underpaid? 3. Team leaders. Many of them are young and incompetent, they're in the lead position either because they know how to please the management or they are the loyalist, therefore, the more experienced talents will suffer big from inexperienced leads and unprofessionalism, they will feel very little chance to exceed unless they become a loyalist too. The team leaders' goals are very much for 360 performance review NOT because they want to bring impact, build a strong team nor nice culture. 4. Benefit. Many thinks employee benefit is good here, well, it maybe the case when the company was small and new here, it has been reducing employee benefits since ever, starts from hard salary negotiation by count in every cent of your flexible benefit and 3 months bonus you may or may not get (depends on how much your leader wants to give you), cheap lunch and snacks that are in trend to become worse due to cut in operation expenditure. 5. Corrupted leaders. Sexual harassment and hostile working environment are quite common, as mentioned, the result of a leader-pleased culture. 6. Resignation. This is a funny one. Let's say if your notice period is one month from 1 Nov to 30 Nov, then you agreed with HRBP to have your last day on 15 Nov, but you do not get paid for 1 Nov to 15 Nov in the end, because you need to pay back to TikTok for the shortened notice period from 16 Nov to 30 Nov! This is the most ridiculous policy i have ever experienced in my life... 7. Future outlook of social media platforms. In overall, weak moat for social media platforms like TikTok, look what happened at Meta and Twitter... TikTok has been expanding in oversea without a concrete plan since 2019, they do not even have headcount projection for each year, which means they could over hire without control. TikTok as the very few APPs that generates revenue, in current economic downturn, ad revenue will shrink, and when a Chinese company cuts its headcount, it can be brutal without anything like Meta gives employees 16 weeks salary, refer to what happened in tech sector in China. 8. My final advise, choose western companies over Chinese companies, for your own value system and mental health. TikTok may try to build its branding, but not if they understand the value of human dignity and respect.

Reviews.Header: Good Career Opportunity and Brand, but Low Compensation and Poor Leadership
Reviews.Pros: 1. Strong Brand Name - very attractive to future employers. 2. People - some great people! Everyone is very helpful and collaborative from day 1. 3. Impact and Scope - The roles are brought and wide allowing for a lot of great projects to work on and stretch yourself. You can build amazing profile and achievements. 4. Daily food allowance and a lot of SWAG 5. Projects - a lot of problems to solve which will build your skills and experience. 6. Super fun and awesome user product. 7. 100% WFH and flexibility, until recently. 8. Speed - great start up speed that is maintained. You will learn to get things done and work fast. 9. High performance environment. 10. Incredible collaborative tools and cloud solutions making collaboration amazing and easy. You can work from any device with easy.
Reviews.Cons: 1. Low Compensation: - TikTok pays WAY less than FAANG closer to Tier 3 companies. - No COL adjustment and only top performing staff get annual increments, based on “perceived performance”. - Only ex-FAANG employees are paid well and have RSUs. The rest are underpaid. 2. Poor Benefits and Insurance - the benefits are below standard and the insurance is bad for a supposedly leading tech company. 3. Poor Management and Leadership: - Many of the senior management are ex-FAANG ICs who are given huge portfolio in TikTok. - In APAC, senior leaders can be incredibly rude. 4. Heavy Perf Review Cycles: - Heavy perf cycles every 6 months with low pay adjustments, if any. - There is no clear guidance on what is high performance. 5. Secretive and Non Transparent: - Nothing is shared with employees and most FTEs are treated like contractors with even basic business data kept private or not allowed to be seen. - No pay bands are shared or explained. - Leaders do not answer questions in town-halls. - The employee survey results are kept secret and not shared even with mid-management. 6. Lack of Investment in the Employees: - The company has no Talent and Development team - Poor training team - No education reimbursements. - No rotation programs are available, either. - No mentorship programs. - No communities 7. WLB - It varies between teams, however overall it is intense. - Often you have to do 2 jobs at the same time with the low pay (see #1). - Your calendar blocks and time is often not respected. 8. Disorganised: - Very disorganised with re-orgs creating teams with no clear roles. - Frequent changes of direction, leaders and strategy. - Many overlapping teams and roles. - Mostly 2 months planning and very frequent changes. 9. No Care for Mental Health - no insurance coverage or care of your mental health and how you feel. Management only cares about revenue. 10. High Attrition and Decline in Talent - Attrition is high with average tenure around 1.5 yrs with some leaving in 2-4 months time. - The company has started to hire mediocre people, at best, or open positions internally only, since they’re can’t afford external candidates in this market.

Reviews.Pros: Slight above average pay Good brand
Reviews.Cons: Depends on which team you are in, WLB can be extremely bad. If your team reports directly to China, you can be working till 12am everyday, 7 days a week during busy period. Managers are professional gaslighter, keep saying that you for not doing enough when you are already working to midnight daily. Toxic environment where people are eager to point finger, steal credit, and throw blame at each other.

Reviews.Header: A good stepping stone into tech but unhealthy to stay!
Reviews.Pros: Competitive salary package if they really want your skill sets, occasional gift boxes, daily free lunch credits, autonomy and flexibility
Reviews.Cons: Culture: Could be real toxic, super political, long hours, many don’t take ownership in their work People: Might have very competitive and showy teammates who will try to outshine you (with dirty tricks) to amaze the manager to get a promotion, lazy and avoid taking more tasks because the manager doesn’t have visibility who is doing what Work: Heavy workload, a lot of redundant and manual work that requires you to spend longer time to complete a task, no proper processes, no KPI to measure your performance, poor communication between teams especially when collaborating on projects Management: In denial, only wanna hear good things, not all managers have leadership. Some don’t care about your wellness (text you at night, keep getting you to do work for him/her to claim credits for, without knowing what you are doing day in day out, pretend to hear your feedback but don’t really make changes). No grooming/mentorship, you’re just on your own, hardly get any feedback to help you improve, more like a machine to repeat your job every day.

Reviews.Pros: IBM is the most innovative company on this planet. I feel so proud to be a part of this technology company that helped landing man on the moon ! The depth of knowledge is so deep and vast that when I get into IBM, I feel like entering a global University. Unlimited learning and huge opportunities. The culture is amazing, the work content is always very satisfying and there is never a stagnation. We can keep rotating to different jobs within the company. In this digital age, the contribution of IBM is so key to the society. The advent of Quantum computing and IBM’s promise to invest 20Bil in the next 10 years is just amazing. I am sure we will be leading the technology of the world, transforming our future generations. If we see the 100+ years of IBM’s journey, the company has sustained many market disruptions, reinvented itself many times and stood solid throughout. When I look back on my long career in IBM, I feel that it is just yesterday ! I am very proud to be a part of the great company. Long live IBM.
Reviews.Cons: Being a large company, some of the decisions are slow. Also, the interdependency on various functions creates too much of bureaucracy, decelerating the decision making process.

We help each other open-mind, coaching and mentoring. - Chance to explore new things that I wanted to explore. Reviews.Header: An antique company desperately trying to stay relevant.
Reviews.Pros: – Work-life balance is moderately alright (but ultimately depends on the project).
Reviews.Cons: – Management gives absolutely no interest in your career goals & aspirations: often empty promises & lip services. Neither do they check-in with you to understand you better nor your current progress. – Way too many mid-management whom no one seems know what they are doing all day except for attending meetings. Too few hands-on staff to carry out the real work – Compensation is below market rates for tech roles. Moreover YOY salary increment, as well as promotion, is negligible. – Benefits are non-existent. Annual paid-leave are minimal. – While local mentorship + networking is a common practice in most MNCs, it's a fairy-tale here. – Interview process has regressed in terms of rigour, resulting in many incompetent IT "talents" populating the workplace in the last 2 years. – Overuse of (cheaper) employees who came from a career-switch background who are not quite yet experienced in running the show. – Projects are poorly executed: what was sold to clients hardly match with the reality on the ground. – Attrition rate is really high for technical staff: knowledge transfer & hand-take are frequent, resulting in many messy sub-projects.

Reviews.Header: Unprofessional experience with Singapore IBM interview/ offer stage for delivery manager
Reviews.Pros: The interview was well conducted with relevant questions on skills and experience
Reviews.Cons: After 3 interviews over a span of 1 month period, I was eventually informed that I successfully pass through the interview and was selected. I was excited and eagerly waiting for my offer and final signing of contract, but it never came. I was told that they don't have the budget to pay my salary after waiting for another month! The recruiter went on to tell me to wait even further for "their business people to discuss further" and they never did reply me to confirm anything. IBM recruiter then ignore my call and email to follow up on my case. This was very disappointing and frustrating. This happened to me despite me telling IBM my current pay and expected new salary right from the start. This is ridiculous and I totally did not expect such bad experience from a global company like IBM.

Reviews.Pros: IBM is the most innovative company on this planet. I feel so proud to be a part of this technology company that helped landing man on the moon ! The depth of knowledge is so deep and vast that when I get into IBM, I feel like entering a global University. Unlimited learning and huge opportunities. The culture is amazing, the work content is always very satisfying and there is never a stagnation. We can keep rotating to different jobs within the company. In this digital age, the contribution of IBM is so key to the society. The advent of Quantum computing and IBM’s promise to invest 20Bil in the next 10 years is just amazing. I am sure we will be leading the technology of the world, transforming our future generations. If we see the 100+ years of IBM’s journey, the company has sustained many market disruptions, reinvented itself many times and stood solid throughout. When I look back on my long career in IBM, I feel that it is just yesterday ! I am very proud to be a part of the great company. Long live IBM.
Reviews.Cons: Being a large company, some of the decisions are slow. Also, the interdependency on various functions creates too much of bureaucracy, decelerating the decision making process.

We help each other open-mind, coaching and mentoring. - Chance to explore new things that I wanted to explore. My boss is also open to discussion and can argue with different opinions. - Compensation and benefit are fair and good for me. - The strategy from management is clear. Reviews.Pros: - For juniors and foreigners looking for a starting career in Singapore, this company is a good stepping stone. This is because this company seems to prefer hiring low wage workers as much as possible. The pattern for juniors and foreigners is to work about 1-2 years and switch to other company. See the cons for long-term career consideration in this company. - Diversity exists, but seems in a bad way (see cons). - There is annual company stock discount for all full-times. - There is online learning coverage for Udemy and Coursera.
Reviews.Cons: - Salary is below the market average, yet job roles can be demanding. - Diversity, mostly are Indonesian, Filipino, Indian, Vietnamese, is likely due to the above point. It is rare to see at least 3rd generation Singaporean in this company's IT and engineering division. If there are any Singaporeans, they are foreigners who had converted to Singaporean. - Promotion is based on both seniority and pleasing the management / French people rather than merits / skills. The effect is brilliant people leave after about 2-3 years of working and those in technical and management roles are filled with the average or bad ones. - Turnover rate is high and this company even gives 2000 SGD for a successful candidate hiring recommendation, close to what this company gives for a successful patent (1000-1500 EUR). - There are several high-ego managers and toxic colleagues. Sabotage and backstabbing do exist and you will be hardly be able to protect yourself when dealing with these toxic people. See the above 2 points on why this is happening. - Most French colleagues I have worked with are cunning, self-entitled, and arrogant towards Asian. It is hard to identify this since they always appear as very friendly. - Politics are strong in higher managements, especially if it is related to French people. - Not many brilliant people to work with and the experts' expertise are questionable. This is a cybersecurity company focused on applied cryptography and yet, most people inside do not have strong cryptography knowledge. - Health insurance coverages are average.

Reviews.Pros: Recommended for Indian India origin. 90% are of indian origin. Eg out of a dept of 180 around 90%are indian. Let's not forget there are other departments too. The other dept too are dominated by Indian. It is very normal to see a reporting structure of up to two or three level of indian mgm before reaching the french mgm. It is very safe for indians as they tend to work behind the door, indian style of management. You will fit very well if you are indian.
Reviews.Cons: If you are non Indian, it could be discouraging. As the culture is heavily leaning towards Indian culture, it easy to face racism, or simply lack of trust among the indian and non-Indian. Not surprising. Important roles or task usually heavily filtered despite how good you are. They tend to hire their own ppl for important task. Non indian will be filtered for low priority tasks. The rest of the non-Indian roles are more more to fill up the quota. But, indian are almost 90% , strange. Does they ever follow the quota? As you 3ill be working with mostly indian hired contract staff, the staff holds onto information due to insecurity. Be prepare that you will be celebrating Indian festive more than any of the national celebration.

Reviews.Header: CACIB ISAP - Management needs a change

Reviews.Pros: Can leave work on time Lots of annual leave System is fast Dual monitors in office
Reviews.Cons: 3 month notice period for all perm staff is a poor way to retain talent. Salary is pathetic compared to market. When this is highlighted to management, they deny this is true. Yet when they hire new staff, they earn more than current staff. It just feels like a KYC factory here. No one cares how u feel or how u are coping. Just do files until u drop dead from exhaustion. Senior management has no KYC experience so they have absolutely no idea on what’s happening on the ground Need to work in office during pandemic even though the job is 95% individual based and requires very little interaction with other colleagues. Now with pandemic over, everyone is 100% working in office. And nobody bothers to ask us if we are ok with coming back to office. We are just told to do so. Turnover rate here very high. People leave after 6 months or less. On the other end, those who can’t find opportunities elsewhere are stuck here for years

Reviews.Header: Socially responsible bank focusing on career growth of its employees
Reviews.Pros: There are a lot of work opportunities and the management focuses on the strengths (mostly) of its staff rather than the weaknesses. Opportunities to explore modern tech stack and processes. Singapore on right path to become real IT twin with Paris (bank's headquarter). Various end to end, global and regional, programs and initiatives are led by teams in Singapore. Plenty of leadership opportunities available at all levels. Solid mentoring and coaching by the entire chain of management. Impressive salary growth in recent past (was an issue before but not anymore)
Reviews.Cons: Being a bank, there are still a lot of obsolete applications with obsolete technology and processes. At-times change can be slow in absence of push from right people.

Mgt wld rather hire new employees than work at retaining seniors resulting in astronomical turnover rates. Within 1 year, most of the seniors have left once they had a job offer and mgt's solution is to mass hire fresh grads who dont know what they are getting themselves into. Training for fresh grads are inefficient and slow resulting in a buildup of backlog files and further exacerbating the vicious cycle. It also does not help that mgt decided to change the system of managing files, resulting in a buildup of backlog since last year when previous workload management was a lot smoother.

Reviews.Pros: Laid-back and lazy, if you call it "Pros". Wait for things to fall in place or NOT fall in place.

(3) Political, cliquey and gossipy (4) Full of suck-ups from India. It is sad that Singapore imports these "foreign talents" from India whom I don't find as "foreign talents" at all. Poor English and unprofessional in their work. (5) Resistant to change (6) Full of red tape and bureaucracies. You can't believe that something simple can involve at least 3 departments to accomplish. Some of them just say "yes/no" without doing anything at all. This is done without contributing significantly to security at all.

Reviews.Pros: • The work is not challenging so you will have more time to focus on other outside activities, like finding a better job. • Lots of foreign employees.
Reviews.Cons: • I had the most toxic and most political managers in my entire work experience. Managers with no humanity will pull you down themselves if they don't like you. • Promotion and salary increase are not output-based or skill-based, but your likability on the perspective of French management. You will witness management favorites get promoted while excellent and hard-working employees who are doing the real work get neglected with measly increase. Performing in year end parties or organizing department outings will give you more chance to be promoted than doing the actual work. • The management is rude to the core and find pleasure in lowering the morale of employees. You will witness managers being racists, making fun of foreign employees' accent, bad-mouthing co-workers, employees who are resigning or resigned, and even counterparts in Paris/overseas. Rude managers will sometimes speak in their native language during meetings to avoid other attendees from participating in the discussion. • In summary, I have a horrible experience working with CACIB.

Reviews.Pros: - Will match comp and level if you're getting hired externally. - Relatively easy to get into. Easier interviews. Good stepping stone if getting opportunity from non FAANG background.
Reviews.Cons: - Not a place for planning you career long term. People will be hired externally on higher levels than someone getting promoted internally despite high performance ratings. - Metrics driven. Managers LOVE numbers, no matter how far-fetched, projected, approximated they are. If you can't show impact in numbers, don't pick up the project. - 3-4 months projects are considered "long term" projects. Don't be mistaken for anything otherwise. Show your impact and move on. - Growth is stagnant in many orgs. Be careful while joining and find out as much as you can during interviews. - No team cares about customers. Good luck if you're joining into sales, account management or support. You're on your own.

Reviews.Pros: Meta offers many great perks, as with the Tech companies.
Reviews.Cons: Do not mistaken the Singapore Data Centre to be the Tech Giant Meta. They are totally different. - The management in data centre does not embody Meta culture. The culture in data centre is worse than small medium enterprises. Employees are expected to be yes men, not to raise any questions or even provide feedback. You'll be targeted by management and your performance appraisal will suffer. - In the data centre, many perks given by Meta are not applicable to you if you are not a manager. Management said you are not to "take advantage of the company " so don't assume the perks such as Global travel days, or even claims of mileage for work purpose to be allowed. They will be rejected by your line manager. - Overall culture is non-supportive and toxic with no flexibility. Expected to work in site office 5 days a week. - Data centre hired people who aren't very competent or capable. It's really puzzling , guess the loop interview is not working. - No career progress, almost impossible to get promoted. - Meta prides itself as a company that supports diversity but the Data centre is a strong supporter of CECA. - Avoid at all costs unless you are a yes man.

Reviews.Header: Good culture unless you are unlucky to get stuck with a wrong manager
Reviews.Pros: I have been associated with Zendesk for close to one year now. Being part of a team catering to internal customers, I have been interacting with not just product teams in Singapore but also from other locations such as Melbourne and Copenhagen. I loved this global exposure and also understood that in general the culture across the organization is empathetic, supportive and encouraging. I love the product that we are building, but the management is not very supportive or encouraging. At multiple occasions, I got the feeling that my concerns are falling on deaf ears, the management is not bold to take a stand, and most concerning, some managers are bringing in a blame culture (which I felt is just against the overall Zendesk culture). Probably, that's the reason, lot of folks from my existing team either moved out or moved to other teams.
Reviews.Cons: So far only one concern; the people management.

Loads of empathy that starts with the CEO and shines through the company. Excellent covid handling: company wide WFH before the government suggested, continued WFH as priority after government lock down ended. Active programmes to help employees disconnect from work. More worried about employees burning out than taking naps, which are also not taboo.

Reviews.Header: Unprofessional and amateur sales management team.
Reviews.Pros: Decent wellness program , modern , well decorated office in Singapore.
Reviews.Cons: The reasons that Asia sales management fail fall into four categories: 1. Direction. Poor understanding of the cloud business in Asia, leading to errors in vision and strategy. 2. Talent. Inability to pick and keep the right people for the team. 3. Execution. Manage people badly, promotion is based on preference not performance. 4. No trust to the team and micromanage , senior sales management initiated 10 by10 exercise which require sales to manually key in activities they do everyday.

Reviews.Header: One Implementation Specialist's View of Zendesk
Reviews.Pros: Zendesk provides a great environment for self-fulfillment and improvement. There are many opportunities and it is relatively open to exploring my interests even if they fall outside of my specific role. For example, I am passionate about learning foreign languages and as a company that has clientele around the globe, there are many conversations in non-English languages. I've been successful at getting myself into many of those conversations even though I was not directly hired for it. Zendesk also has an inclusive and welcoming environment. I have worked at the office in Madison and in Singapore and both have felt this way. The company organizes many events and is inclusive of all employees to participate. There is also an awesome feeling of empowerment both on the job and in the larger community. CSR is an important part of our job and even though I don't participate as much as others, it feels great to see our CEO so active. Lastly, it is open in terms of rank and file employees approaching management or senior management to express concerns or to socialize.
Reviews.Cons: As a new company, many policies and procedures are not clearly defined, frequently change, or are simply not good. I think that as it is raplidly growing there is also constant change, which can be good for the opportunity it provides, but also bad as the structure can often be insufficient. There is also a lot of change as Zendesk continues transitioning away from start-up mentality (1600+ employees) to more corporate: more bureaucracy, more inflexible policies, more segmentation and siloing of responsibilities. Though these can be good things in ways, they can also be very negative for one seeking the openness and flexibility of startup.

Reviews.Cons: Company strongly focuses on outsourcing and belies any project can be done with quickly trained individuals. Very little people in SG have professional cloud certs and it looks like the management can't sustain higher pay for tech people (if you're tech skilled, just go to FAANG). They prefer to rely on offshore people and just focus on project management The management likes long term planning e.g. five year plans... There's no incentive to develop personally unless told in top-down manner by management It looks like consultants are oversold to clients, so they expect professionals, not juniors. My client that was using company services was so angry because of what they got, they were hostile to consultants and eventually stopped cooperation. Such approach is not uncommon, clients can be obnoxious towards consultants and the management even can't do much because at the end of the day, clients gives money... The fact that no one in the local management is in their 50's, is very worrisome. It means that the company couldn't develop strong enough business, so that more mature people would join them. I felt bad when was talking with some of the people from management, because of their immaturity

Reviews.Pros: Onboarding project (also called TW launch) was a great time together working as a team. I was surprised by the scale of it. There was a lot of effort done behind the scene for new joiners to have an amazing learning experience on TW ways of working. Personally it was a good refresher on Agile practices. Thanks to the whole team, each and every one brought their past experience and learnings to the table and we all worked together for a common goal with excellent team dynamics. Both trainers hosted all the sessions very well and guided each and everyone of us. Initial few days before onboarding project was also engaging time with lot of things to go through. All the activities were well planned and were very smooth. It didn’t feel like one is starting fresh in a new organisation.
Reviews.Cons: In person interaction is always better than remote, and its even more important for a new member. Its a shame due to covid restrictions this couldnt have been better. However given the situation team did well with onboarding.

Reviews.Pros: Onboarding was really smooth and informative considering that there were covid restrictions. There is a flat hierarchy here and people are generally very nice and helpful. HR also checks in frequently and it feels like they do take our opinions into consideration.
Reviews.Cons: None for now (only a few months in)

Reviews.Header: A great place to grow and learn as a professional and as a person
Reviews.Pros: - Great culture, people care about you, they care about each other and also they are very smart and nice to work with - The leaders in Thoughtworks cares about people's opinion and work hard to improve processes and experience of Thoughtworkers. - Great learning environment. If you are a proactive person, you are willing to learn and grow there are multiple opportunities for you to learn. - High integrity, the values of Thoughtworks are oriented to pursue the right attitude, aptitude, and integrity. This makes a very nice place to learn from each other. - Very high level of autonomy.
Reviews.Cons: - There is so much to do, work, learn that sometimes could feel overwhelming. But it is up to looking for support to navigate the culture.

Reviews.Pros: My many of years in candidate management has leveraged my learning in TW.
Reviews.Cons: Prepare for learning everyday everyminute

Reviews.Header: Great culture and focus on people!
Reviews.Pros: - The company in general and the Singapore office focusses a lot on growing people and giving them opportunities to step up and shine - Great place to work if you are self motivated and like to control and drive your career and shape it the way you want - Normal for people to join as a developer and then switch across roles, complete flexibility. - Lot of training and capability building opportunities for all TWers and a good personal development budget for every TWer. I had the opportunity to attend a conference in Berlin using the budget. - The People (HR) team is awesome, and they focus on ensuring every TWer is looked after and provided the necessary support. - For most of the projects, as technical consultants we are given the opportunity to shape the product and decide the infrastructure - Probably the first technical team I have worked as a developer where the gender diversity ration is exactly 1:1.
Reviews.Cons: - Although working hours are quite balanced, sometimes a little bit extra effort is required, especially closer to delivery dates. - Not be the highest payer in the market when it comes to compensation, but employees are attracted by the culture and focus on people. - Might be a bit challenging for folks who are waiting to get direction or too used to working for a manager.

Reviews.Header: Good and sucks in some ways
Reviews.Pros: Great work place, great company culture.
Reviews.Cons: Unavoidable OT in some teams

Reviews.Pros: Surrounded by great people with a big knowledge sharing culture. A lot of learning channels and opportunities, even at higher level.
Reviews.Cons: As with any consulting job, your experience will depend of the mission you get.

Reviews.Pros: - Leadership does see themselves as leadership instead of "management", and listens to the ground, while balancing business growth. Having been in previous companies before that have competent leadership too, this stands out. - Pivoted to remote work due to C19 swiftly despite complexity of having to manage client expectations. Was also easy since TW has operated on a trust-basis in terms of working hours from a long time ago. - structure of company is improving since before the sale of the company to APAX, more consistency and transparency as a result. - Keen focus on growth and cultivation, not just lip service. Internal capability growth tools and sessions on top of personal development budget. - Colleagues are outstanding and high-calibre.
Reviews.Cons: - Compensation & benefits is just alright. Definitely has room to improve versus the market. - While technical skills of teammates are great, soft skills gap can sometimes be seen in certain client situations.

Reviews.Pros: The organisation has a flat hierarchy, so it is easy to voice out your opinions and feel safe about it. It is also very open about decision-making, and the company values everyone’s opinions.
Reviews.Cons: The main downside for me is the pay (I work with more junior DEVs from our partners with a much higher pay). Other than that, the organisation emphasises a lot on sharing and self-improvement, which gets hard to cope with after awhile.

Reviews.Header: Great company culture but depends on the project you're staffed on.
Reviews.Pros: Vibrant community, company talks, really cool people, nice pantry, interesting challenges, nice perks, good brand name, international community, company mission, commitment to diversity (not just lip service). In general, probably the most fun tech company you can work for in Singapore.
Reviews.Cons: Too many govt projects, unclear career progression, business functions a little unclear, compensation not competitive (no bonus), some projects a lot more stressful than others, big difference in capabilities within the same grade/level.

Reviews.Pros: 1. Unlike other IT consultancies out there, consultants in TW really pay attention to software quality, devops automation and good coding practices. This is a good place to learn these skills. 2. There are many project sharing sessions, books clubs event etc. 3. No jerks policy - Many TW-ers you will meet are very friendly and jerks usually do not last long in TW. The management takes care of employees even during Covid-19 by sending snacks and hand-written cards.
Reviews.Cons: 1. Echoing what the previous reviews mentioned, there are limited trainings available in TW SEA. To add more details, most of the trainings in SEA are tapping onto programmes conducted by other TW offices or conducted by consultants who happen to be free. In SEA, there are also only 2-3 training licenses (e.g. PluralSight) being shared and rotated among hundreds of consultants and you can only keep one license for 3 months which is hardly enough. The personal training budget is also insufficient. 2. There are usually gaps between what was promised pre-hire and after hire. Have spoken to many new folks who are interested and expecting to do frontend or analytics from their interviews conversations but were all staffed to be full stack engineers. This might be because interviews, staffing and actual projects are handled by different people who are not aligned. 3. Attrition is high. Experienced consultants usually leave after a year or two, usually for higher compensation or job scopes better aligned with their own career interests. At the same time, there are many fresh graduates being hired. While I agree we can train fresh grads to be good developers, it will take time. We need to retain more experienced and talented individuals in TW first. This trend of TW SEA becoming bottom-heavy in terms of experience is getting worrisome for slips in capabilities and quality.

Reviews.Header: Very positive experience, might not be for everyone.
Reviews.Pros: - A very good place to pick up software development best practices. - Lots of amazing colleagues to work with and learn from - Good support available - Various other activities outside the daily work to be a part of - Self-directed learning; your interests at your pace
Reviews.Cons: - If you're someone who needs to be told what to do next, this may not be the place for you. - Work life balance really depends on the project you're on, and your time management.

Reviews.Pros: - The company is huge on continuous learning, people you meet in the company generally will be very driven to learn and grow their skills. This is also supported by the company's dedicated personal budget for learning each employee is entitled to as well as learning platform. - Flat hierarchy - Both senior and junior devs have almost equal standing when it comes to voicing your opinions in team discussions. Junior devs are very much encouraged to be active in technical discussions and get to work closely with clients - You have the freedom and space of what you want to focus on and you'll be supported by your team/company. For example, you can focus more on being Infrastructure Engineer after a period of time focusing on App Development. - Really appreciate the feedback culture in the company - Most teams will practice regular feedback so you'll know where you stand and keep improving. - Some ThoughtWorkers are thought leaders in the industry too, it is very normal to see colleagues speaking at conferences, writing books, etc - Personally find it very inspiring. - The company is also huge and serious in making social impact in the world. There is a dedicated coordinator for all the social initiatives driven by the company, making it easier for employees to be engaged in social initiatives sustainably.
Reviews.Cons: - Since the company is in consulting business, there will be times when you're on the beach (or bench, in general consulting term). During this time, you will not be working on client projects but you're expected to drive your own learning. - Lateral-hire training/onboarding can be better. Felt quite lost when I joined the company at first. And teams are generally working in silos in each client project, so if you're new and has no projects yet, it can be tough to get to know other employees. - Salary-wise is not the highest in the industry. Though there is 13th month bonus, there isn't performance-related bonus.

Reviews.Header: good place for learning, hard to get career progression.
Reviews.Pros: - good learning environment - promotes diversity and inclusiveness - great work life balance
Reviews.Cons: - they are very big on "culture" but if you look deeper, alot of people are just fake and trying to fit in and be what they think the company expects them to be. - difficult to attain career progression as quite flat structured

Reviews.Pros: TW overall is a good company but try to avoid design because of design leaders.
Reviews.Cons: Company says they want to focus and grow the design so they decided to put two head of design for a team of 20 people? which doesn't make any sense. I have been working with them for quite a long time now and I can say both lack design skills and the leader mindset.  All they can do is just one thing... "TALK". Both can't deliver. I doubt if they have ever done any end to end design delivery.  Both head of design behave like mothers "do this, do that". They don't want to give autonomy to the team and want to control everything. Yup almost everything. e.g if both are busy the team gets messages like we can't make it today, let's cancel today's meet. We'll put something new" which never happens. Every team conversation is just about two buzz words, 'Value' and 'Impact' but the team always wonders what exactly does that mean? I bet just like the team they also don't know what both words are and they just use them to show off. It's quite common in the office to use buzz words. Both ladies have two faces. One for TW & SG leadership team and this face is very shiny, everything is going excellent, we are leaders and design is adding tremendous value, another one is with a team which is very dark and scary. There is literally zero team communication which happens because nobody has any interest. Why because both leaders fail to create that environment for the team which TW MD's and HR failed to see and understand.Team feels both are incapable and lousy design leaders. It's just no one wants to talk about this because all they care about is just doing the job and getting a salary. Everyone in the design team is on the verge of leaving TW because of these two. Maybe that's the reason people have started moving out of TW. There are other tons of points but i know nothing will happen because TW MD's will just talk to these two and both are smart enough to cover and brainwash MD's. It's just hopeless. They have decided to hire Sr and Lead designers instead of promoting internally. Why? Because both leaders fail to connect designers/team or mentor designers so that they can grow.  All both care about is their 'own' growth and faking around. Question is who will save TW SG Design team?

Reviews.Pros: Flat management and engineering culture
Reviews.Cons: Pros are disappearing gradually as company has profit pressure after being purchased.

Reviews.Pros: Good welfare，good colleagues and good career progression
Reviews.Cons: None I can think of

Reviews.Header: A good place for a developer to grow
Reviews.Pros: - Very supportive colleagues and working environment. (aka no "jerks" policy) - Work in a team with knowledgable and inspiring technical people, which you can learn new things from - Project teams always carefully crafted to have a higher percentage of seniors and mid level developers as compared to juniors (aka your project will probably go smoothly and no death march) - Deployment of software is always through the automated Continuous Integration/ Deployment pipeline (aka no fear to release new version software, and no staying back late after working hours to fix deployment issue) - Get to be assigned to different projects, which means you get experience in many different languages and technologies to beef up your resume - This is a consulting job, so we have the chance to improve your tech communication skills, as you get to interact with clients (not a job where you just code), which will definitely be valuable in your future career. - There are often office events, and get togethers where we can interact with other teams, (aka: no silos) - Generous salary, and other benefits where the company foots your mobile and internet bill
Reviews.Cons: - Not really a con, but due to the supportive environment, you will not get direct pressure from the higher ups to improve yourself. So over here it is important to plan your career aims and have the self motivation to stick to it. - As your fellow colleagues are always pushing the limit, this is not a place for someone who does not like change or getting out of their comfort zone.

Reviews.Pros: Flat hierarchy Friendly and open culture that is open to help Good software engineering practices
Reviews.Cons: Compensation could have been better

Reviews.Pros: Professionalism and team. Multiple projects to work on
Reviews.Cons: It's a service company- dealing with unhappy clients.

Reviews.Header: Best place to progress in career
Reviews.Pros: - Amazing colleagues, you can learn many things from the people around you. - Project line up is good. - Makes you a better human being by making you think from holistic perspective by internally sharing the news on culture, values, global issues, environment, social and economic issues. - There is a lot of scope to learn new technologies. - Most of the times you'll be pairing with the senior developers, this gives you great opportunities to share your thoughts as well as learn from others. This act of pairing with others expedites your learning.
Reviews.Cons: - Work life balance: In most of the cases, ThoughtWorks takes up very critical and rescue based projects. Because of the nature of the projects, you need to be expert in a technology to solve the issues that occur during the development. And at the same time, it is very difficult, especially in these modern days, to learn many tools and technologies out there in the market. This creates lots of pressure on the developers and makes you to work harder and thus leading to bad work life balance. After you learn these skills in a project you are shifted to another project that demands some other skillsets. For junior developers this is good as they can learn many technologies in their early career. But for mid to senior developers, you'll be constantly (or implicitly) assessed by peers creating lots of pressure to learn lots of tools in a short period of time and you need to prove by delivering the project as well. ThoughtWorks management should understand this situation and should provide right kind of support.

Reviews.Pros: - great company with a focus on people
Reviews.Cons: - recently been hiring at a very rapid rate

Reviews.Pros: A flexible workspace and nice mates
Reviews.Cons: Too many office politics in the leads and principles, they don't respect tech excellent nowadays.

Reviews.Pros: - Well-diverse environment. Different countries, races, religions, genders work together. - Invests a lot in people. They have budget for books and training sessions as well. - Open-minded. Anyone can voice out opinions. - Trust in people. Work timing is generally flexible. - Flat hierarchy. No red-tapes. - True advocate in Agile and Technologies. - Work with the best people. Everyone is friendly as well. - Work in Teams. No one gets left behind. - Plenty of opportunities to travel or get staffed overseas. - Good pantry! ThoughtWorks embrace differences in people.
Reviews.Cons: - Interviews are not easy, especially if you're applying for the tech role - Need to keep learning so as to keep up with the variety of projects available - Tend to always encounter new things, hence there's always a pressure to learn things fast - Sometimes they expect too much out of the people so it might be a little stressful depending on how you take it.

Reviews.Pros: Good benefits, great team, and many interesting projects
Reviews.Cons: Some internal politics due to management

Reviews.Pros: Benefits only. If you’re into getting quick bucks on your savings account, start here, but prepare to withstand one of the world's most toxic corporate culture.
Reviews.Cons: Remember reading all those posts on internet about companies with toxic cultures, bad management and politics politics and more politics in their corporate culture? Yeah, Dyson somehow managed to have all of it under their roof. Think of a shiny golden Fabergé egg on the outside and rotten tomatoes inside, and you’ll get the picture. You’ll be treated like a number, you’ll be asked to work overtime, you’ll be pushed to work on weekends and stay away from your family. You’ll be asked to work during your holidays and while you’re sick. I’m not kidding or exaggerating. Prepare for it. And they’ll tell you, it’s harsh times and this and that and it’s for the greater good and for your and the company’s benefit to do so, but they won’t offer anything in return. They’ll thank you at the end. But you don’t work for thank you, now do you!? Your time away from the family will be lost forever, your holidays will be ruined when your phone starts ringing where they ask you to go back the work, because the top management Gods have to be satisfied, because the mile long train can never stop! You’ll be frantically bombarded with a “self-help” e-mails teaching you how to reduce the stress, how to cope with the symptoms. That’s your sign, right there, to ruuuuuun! Run as far as you can and get yourself a nice job, anywhere else, except here!

Reviews.Header: Was a great place to work at but now falling into ruins

Reviews.Header: Good place to start career as Engineer

Reviews.Header: Its a nice company to work in,but no choice to leave with a heavy heart
Reviews.Pros: -Benefits(annual leave,flexi etc) -Free and easy office culture -Free lunch and coffee -Staff discount -Personal work laptop -High pay for degree holders only(engineer level and above)
Reviews.Cons: -One of the poorly handled management in STC test department -Team lead has no leadership capability doesn't mingle and bond with the team, Lack of PR skills and have mood swings/attitude every once in awhile. -Workaholic environment,working till 10pm onwards for some people -Poor progression(Hierarchy and salary) -No proper clarity on department objective -Applied for test department role as a shift worker, came in only to find out doing office hours totally misleading on dyson website. -Team lead lack of care and concern to the team members -Different management of team as STC test team reports to MDC and MDC will not fully understand what is going on with the people internally within STC test team so it can be frustrating. -Management only care about KPI and not the hard work or welfare of the techs. -No free parking -Workload can be heavy and insufficient manpower -Shift allowance is low at STC

Reviews.Pros: Benefits decent with good leave

Reviews.Pros: - Generally good work life balance - Dress down everyday
Reviews.Cons: - Decisions can't be made in a resolute manner. A lot of people sitting on the fence and refuse to make a decision, causing much unnecessary stress to the people down the food chain who have to do the actual work. - Male dominated company - talk about diversity but don't walk the talk. - Dealing with RDD is awful - they think they are king and often belittle other functions and departments when they should be collaborating as peers/equals instead. This is worse than being a chaotic circus. - Not much opportunities for promotion. Very dependent on who your boss sucks up to. - Mid to senior management are mostly people of a certain race.

( Work is not very challenging though, so fair game)
Reviews.Cons: - Not very focus on performance, most of the services' code look clean but is actually inefficient when u pay attention to space and time complexity. - Heavily dependent on AWS. - Significantly smaller scale compared to tech companies in the industry.

Reviews.Pros: Friendly colleagues at working level

Reviews.Header: All things considered, it's not bad, but could be a lot better
Reviews.Pros: Decent pay (some might consider it low for Software Engineers), decent work life balance, decent perks(health/benefits). Staff discounts are nice but not amazing. Colleagues ( direct team members and manager ) are decent people, but honestly there's no real interaction other than work which makes it super unmotivating.
Reviews.Cons: Management is lacking. Seems to have a pretty high attrition rate, despite upper management saying "Oh it's less than x%, we are doing good" Extremely stingy on sending employees on proper, official courses to get training. Lack of proper structure in getting new hires up to speed. Performance reviews feel like an empty shell, it seems near impossible to get the 'higher' ranks of review and at best everyone is just given the 'average' performance. If I took the time to organise and plan external activities OUTSIDE of my jobscope FOR the company multiple times, and I still only get an "average" review, then I'm sorry, I don't think I will put in the extra effort anymore. Upper management seems to still idolize the "start-up" vibe where everything is "open-concept" and "collaborating" despite now being a huge company that obviously cannot follow such ideals without proper adjustments. If you want collaboration, yet also want "secrecy" where any employee not involved in a particular project is NOT allowed to know anything about it, how would you even do that? It's just contradictory. Also, hot-desking just kills any possible attachment one would have to go to office. Bring in the point that upper management seems like they refuse to entertain the idea of permanent WFH (without govt intervention), it just seems like a recipe for losing employees in this current COVID era. There is simply no proper office culture as to speak, and without dedicated team seating and areas no one will willingly mingle and interact given the current situation there. Edited this review for the recent OMICRON surge in SG: Despite the large surge, we still get an 'official notice' to be 'encouraged' to go back to office, when it is actually mandatory to go back to office 3 days a week. All this despite WFH having no significant impact on our work (as software engineers)

Reviews.Header: You don't need Indeed.com to find one of the best employers in Singapore!
Reviews.Pros: I felt valued from day 1. I was treated with respect by very senior leaders within the company and that my opinions mattered. There were ample opportunities for growth and plenty of support to do what's important. The culture at Indeed is just wonderful. People were always helpful and not only is it encouraged - it is recognized and rewarded. Indeed does not practice "stack ranking" during performance evaluations which promotes a high level of collaboration between individuals. Evaluations and promotions are highly transparent, which meant that every individual knew what it takes for their own career progression. The engineering teams in Singapore contribute to efforts that are crucial to Indeed's global machinery. What one does impacts all of Indeed worldwide - the teams here contribute to efforts across very different domains, ranging from payments and apply to our salary and educations product that are used by more than 250m active jobseekers worldwide. There are no lack of interesting, impactful problems to solve! Compensation for engineering in Indeed is one of the best in the Singapore tech landscape. This is supplemented by excellent healthcare and other "standard" tech benefits like daily catered meals, well stocked pantry and flexible working hours. To prevent people from burning out, Indeed instituted monthly "You days" which are Indeed wide holidays for all employees. On top of that, all employees have unlimited paid-time-off and managers would actively encourage their teammates to utilize this benefit. It is very clear that leadership all the way from the top cares about a healthy work-life balance here in Indeed. Indeed also embraces working remotely. While the offices have reopened, all employees have the flexibility to work from home or from the office. Indeed provides a small monthly stipend as a WFH allowance. You won't regret joining Indeed!
Reviews.Cons: The lack of brand prestige working for Indeed is about the only minus I can think of. Indeed is relatively unknown here and that limits Indeed's ability to hire well in this market.

Reviews.Pros: Great work-life balance, extensive health benefits, free daily lunches, fun colleagues
Reviews.Cons: Limited career progression and growth

Reviews.Pros: Indeed truly takes care of you and your wellbeing.
Reviews.Cons: Nothing at the moment hah!

Reviews.Header: Challenging yet wonderful experience in my career
Reviews.Pros: From day 1, I felt very welcomed and included at Indeed. Their culture of transparency and providing consistent support to their employees wellbeing has undoubtedly set me up for success in my career and to develop my personal growth. While there is a lot of learning about the product and how to explain it in layman terms, Indeed provided a lot of training opportunities and coaching from experienced managers to help you achieve your goals. If you work in Sales, it will be a challenging experience and it's important to be on top of your book of business. However, if you disqualify, manage your time and focus on the clients that want to talk to you and need your help, then you will reach your quota and open a lot of doors for your personal brand as well as expand your network. I learned so much from Indeed, my managers, and peers that hone in on my soft skills so no doubt that it made me more resilient and adaptive to the current environment and more importantly work effectively as a team to reach our goals. Other nice perks include unlimited PTO, work-home balance, work from home allowance and free swag.
Reviews.Cons: Communication with other teams located in different offices across the globe can lead to delays in getting campaigns started and issues resolved which can be frustrating. Sometimes they ask you to create a ticket again after raising the incorrect one or if there is information missing, you need to start from the beginning in raising a case again. This sort of admin work is unnecessary and adds to an already heavy workload to AEs so if there is a little flexibility introduced to this then it would really drive results faster. When you sell an annual subscription, you can only receive a quarter of the revenue added to your dash each quarter. If the account moves to Growth then the new rep gets the remaining revenue due despite the fact that you closed an annual deal.

Reviews.Pros: Great company with flexible policies
Reviews.Cons: NA. nothing to complain about

Reviews.Header: Company with great culture & employee benefits
Reviews.Pros: Great team culture & employee benefits. Leaders are open to listening to your opinions & addressing your challenges.
Reviews.Cons: Lack of career development. Take a long time to implement process & product changes.

Reviews.Header: Sub-standard quality of work, below avg team, but with great pay
Reviews.Pros: - People are generally friendly and good to talk to - Pay is top of the market for Singapore. Since they have limited brand value in the market, they pay big bucks to compensate to buy out people from other companies.
Reviews.Cons: - Lots of talk, but little real action: Since Indeed in Singapore hires a lot more “managers who talk fancy” rather than “actual doers”, there’s very little work that actually gets accomplished on a weekly basis. Most work gets caught up in holding patterns of useless debates/micro-alignment, and eventually teams celebrate tiny A/B tests at the end of 3 months as “massive impact”. The actual amount of work that gets each quarter is a joke, really! - The office is pretty much a satellite engineering office for the most part: Strategy/goals gets “handed down from the top” from US bosses. Or even if the teams come up with bottom-up ideas — they need “permission from the top” to even try it out. The culture is very top-down for the most part. - The management in the US doesn’t trust the teams in Singapore, hence prepare to be micro-managed a lot. Have a problem with micro-management? Sorry, you’re not “aligned” — don’t even try pushing back as micro-management (ex: getting your simple A/B experiments approved before testing) is the expected cultural norm here. - Culture in Singapore reminds you a lot of working in a large bank: Lots of politics, people sweet-talking on the face while they complain behind your back, lots of talk around process yet very little work actually gets done, leaders who do a lot of theoretical pseudo-intellectual debates but with little practical implementation knowledge nor experience. - Hiring processes are broken: The quality of the people varies a lot. You might find an occasional outlier rockstar but huge variations in quality of folks. From a Singapore standpoint, the overall avg engineering quality is definitely below market, and part of it can also be attributed to the quality of product-mandates held by Singapore teams — since the work is not very challenging, you don’t tend to attract the best engineers anyways! How many engineers would just want to move around a couple of buttons everyday?
