Reviews.Header: Worst management team, you'll regret to join here
Reviews.Pros: Great employee perks including top class health insurances, free drinks and snacks
Reviews.Cons: The worst working experience I've ever encountered. -No work life balance. In the interview, I was told there is awesome work life balance here, and almost no OT here which is totally not the truth. You are expected to work 10-12 hours a day. Though it's not enforced directly, it is implied by team lead and manager. They assigned you the overwhelmed work to do which is even out of your job scope, then told you that you can stop your work at 6pm. But the workload is definitely couldn't be finished before 6pm. Even you sacrifice yourself and work overtime every day, the work will never be completed. Because they keep assigning you the work more and more, and lastly give you the worst and false evaluation even though how hard you worked. -Poor management. Poorest management team, you couldn’t imagine a team can be leaded by these kinds of people: they are emotional, unprofessional, childish, lack of basic working knowledge. They couldn’t accept any different voice, and keep building “yes-man” around them. The leads keep making mistakes but all will become subordinate’s faults, that’s their way. -Office politics. It’s so funny even there is office politics in such a small team, and 2 team leads in the same team. The power-hungry leads use their subordinates as a tool to fight for their promotion. So, subordinates must become victims. -Border bullying culture Harassment behavior from team leaders and managers. Even they have an ethical team or HR department who should take care of this kind of issue, and you reported to them you have mentally exhausted due to endless border bullying, but no one take care of this issue seriously, and no one will care you, anyway you’re replaceable. And the team leader even told you, if you couldn’t endure then quit here.

Reviews.Pros: Global community, some people who worked at the company during better times are still there, in the US/Europe OCTO people that compile Tech Radar are nice although they are based in the US/Europe Good projects for graduates
Reviews.Cons: Company strongly focuses on outsourcing and belies any project can be done with quickly trained individuals. Very little people in SG have professional cloud certs and it looks like the management can't sustain higher pay for tech people (if you're tech skilled, just go to FAANG). They prefer to rely on offshore people and just focus on project management The management likes long term planning e.g. five year plans... There's no incentive to develop personally unless told in top-down manner by management It looks like consultants are oversold to clients, so they expect professionals, not juniors. My client that was using company services was so angry because of what they got, they were hostile to consultants and eventually stopped cooperation. Such approach is not uncommon, clients can be obnoxious towards consultants and the management even can't do much because at the end of the day, clients gives money... The fact that no one in the local management is in their 50's, is very worrisome. It means that the company couldn't develop strong enough business, so that more mature people would join them. I felt bad when was talking with some of the people from management, because of their immaturity

Reviews.Pros: Care about the people, no office politics
Reviews.Cons: No business ambitions, operation inefficiency

Reviews.Pros: Onboarding project (also called TW launch) was a great time together working as a team. I was surprised by the scale of it. There was a lot of effort done behind the scene for new joiners to have an amazing learning experience on TW ways of working. Personally it was a good refresher on Agile practices. Thanks to the whole team, each and every one brought their past experience and learnings to the table and we all worked together for a common goal with excellent team dynamics. Both trainers hosted all the sessions very well and guided each and everyone of us. Initial few days before onboarding project was also engaging time with lot of things to go through. All the activities were well planned and were very smooth. It didn’t feel like one is starting fresh in a new organisation.
Reviews.Cons: In person interaction is always better than remote, and its even more important for a new member. Its a shame due to covid restrictions this couldnt have been better. However given the situation team did well with onboarding.

Reviews.Header: Challenging yet fulfilling place to work

Reviews.Cons: It can be a little tricky internally, you need to gain social capital to succeed here. Managing internal stakeholders can be more difficult than managing client. You need to be of certain personality to excel here. Work life balance is project dependent.

Reviews.Pros: good company, culture, flat hierarchy

Reviews.Header: Great place to work, if you enjoy consulting.

Reviews.Cons: Consulting is not for everyone. You get good clients, and you'll get bad clients. Most people who leave ThoughtWorks do so because of poor experiences with terrible clients.

Reviews.Pros: Truly supports your growth and development

Reviews.Pros: TW hires very consistently across different roles. But at the very core, everyone is independent and has something that they are passionate about. Learning is also a huge part of their culture - there is a lot of support from fellow employees and resources are available for one to explore any topics that they are keen to find out more.
Reviews.Cons: Probably not suited for people who prefers to climb the career level or are not inquisitive by nature.

Reviews.Header: It's a great place to work!
Reviews.Pros: Flexibility in roles Autonomous Culture - free to drive your own initiatives Supportive and talented people

Reviews.Pros: Treats technology really seriously, from coding to people to project management and impact/value Guaranteed excellent foundation and learning compared to many companies not doing things right - dedicated time during onboarding for exposure to agile development practices, time to learn on the bench Development practices are XP inspired, no joke TDD, TBD, CI/CD Strategy to differentiate from other consulting companies opens up opportunities Extremely strong feedback culture Growth/ career pathway is self-directed, evening crossing functions
Reviews.Cons: New challenges after going public, need to not lose the best of culture while growing fast After all a services company, need to know if it's what you want

Reviews.Pros: - Great opportunity to learn, there are a lot of things to do and you never get bored. - Great culture - Great people
Reviews.Cons: - Requires patience if coming from a different company culture, like more hierarchical or structure, but it is worth it.

Reviews.Pros: Working at Thoughtworks - Supportive and collaborative culture.

Reviews.Cons: However, that’s what it is - an outsourcing company still. There is little product or technology innovation nowadays. Still a really good company to learn from.

Reviews.Pros: Nice compensation and colleagues, no micro management

Reviews.Pros: Great culture and great people

Reviews.Pros: Onboarding was really smooth and informative considering that there were covid restrictions. There is a flat hierarchy here and people are generally very nice and helpful. HR also checks in frequently and it feels like they do take our opinions into consideration.
Reviews.Cons: None for now (only a few months in)

Reviews.Header: A great place to grow and learn as a professional and as a person
Reviews.Pros: - Great culture, people care about you, they care about each other and also they are very smart and nice to work with - The leaders in Thoughtworks cares about people's opinion and work hard to improve processes and experience of Thoughtworkers. - Great learning environment. If you are a proactive person, you are willing to learn and grow there are multiple opportunities for you to learn. - High integrity, the values of Thoughtworks are oriented to pursue the right attitude, aptitude, and integrity. This makes a very nice place to learn from each other. - Very high level of autonomy.
Reviews.Cons: - There is so much to do, work, learn that sometimes could feel overwhelming. But it is up to looking for support to navigate the culture.

Reviews.Pros: My many of years in candidate management has leveraged my learning in TW.
Reviews.Cons: Prepare for learning everyday everyminute

Reviews.Header: Great culture and focus on people!
Reviews.Pros: - The company in general and the Singapore office focusses a lot on growing people and giving them opportunities to step up and shine - Great place to work if you are self motivated and like to control and drive your career and shape it the way you want - Normal for people to join as a developer and then switch across roles, complete flexibility. - Lot of training and capability building opportunities for all TWers and a good personal development budget for every TWer. I had the opportunity to attend a conference in Berlin using the budget. - The People (HR) team is awesome, and they focus on ensuring every TWer is looked after and provided the necessary support. - For most of the projects, as technical consultants we are given the opportunity to shape the product and decide the infrastructure - Probably the first technical team I have worked as a developer where the gender diversity ration is exactly 1:1.
Reviews.Cons: - Although working hours are quite balanced, sometimes a little bit extra effort is required, especially closer to delivery dates. - Not be the highest payer in the market when it comes to compensation, but employees are attracted by the culture and focus on people. - Might be a bit challenging for folks who are waiting to get direction or too used to working for a manager.

Reviews.Header: Good and sucks in some ways
Reviews.Pros: Great work place, great company culture.
Reviews.Cons: Unavoidable OT in some teams

Reviews.Pros: Surrounded by great people with a big knowledge sharing culture. A lot of learning channels and opportunities, even at higher level.
Reviews.Cons: As with any consulting job, your experience will depend of the mission you get.

Reviews.Pros: - Leadership does see themselves as leadership instead of "management", and listens to the ground, while balancing business growth. Having been in previous companies before that have competent leadership too, this stands out. - Pivoted to remote work due to C19 swiftly despite complexity of having to manage client expectations. Was also easy since TW has operated on a trust-basis in terms of working hours from a long time ago. - structure of company is improving since before the sale of the company to APAX, more consistency and transparency as a result. - Keen focus on growth and cultivation, not just lip service. Internal capability growth tools and sessions on top of personal development budget. - Colleagues are outstanding and high-calibre.
Reviews.Cons: - Compensation & benefits is just alright. Definitely has room to improve versus the market. - While technical skills of teammates are great, soft skills gap can sometimes be seen in certain client situations.

Reviews.Pros: The organisation has a flat hierarchy, so it is easy to voice out your opinions and feel safe about it. It is also very open about decision-making, and the company values everyone’s opinions.
Reviews.Cons: The main downside for me is the pay (I work with more junior DEVs from our partners with a much higher pay). Other than that, the organisation emphasises a lot on sharing and self-improvement, which gets hard to cope with after awhile.

Reviews.Header: Great company culture but depends on the project you're staffed on.
Reviews.Pros: Vibrant community, company talks, really cool people, nice pantry, interesting challenges, nice perks, good brand name, international community, company mission, commitment to diversity (not just lip service). In general, probably the most fun tech company you can work for in Singapore.
Reviews.Cons: Too many govt projects, unclear career progression, business functions a little unclear, compensation not competitive (no bonus), some projects a lot more stressful than others, big difference in capabilities within the same grade/level.

Reviews.Pros: 1. Unlike other IT consultancies out there, consultants in TW really pay attention to software quality, devops automation and good coding practices. This is a good place to learn these skills. 2. There are many project sharing sessions, books clubs event etc. 3. No jerks policy - Many TW-ers you will meet are very friendly and jerks usually do not last long in TW. The management takes care of employees even during Covid-19 by sending snacks and hand-written cards.
Reviews.Cons: 1. Echoing what the previous reviews mentioned, there are limited trainings available in TW SEA. To add more details, most of the trainings in SEA are tapping onto programmes conducted by other TW offices or conducted by consultants who happen to be free. In SEA, there are also only 2-3 training licenses (e.g. PluralSight) being shared and rotated among hundreds of consultants and you can only keep one license for 3 months which is hardly enough. The personal training budget is also insufficient. 2. There are usually gaps between what was promised pre-hire and after hire. Have spoken to many new folks who are interested and expecting to do frontend or analytics from their interviews conversations but were all staffed to be full stack engineers. This might be because interviews, staffing and actual projects are handled by different people who are not aligned. 3. Attrition is high. Experienced consultants usually leave after a year or two, usually for higher compensation or job scopes better aligned with their own career interests. At the same time, there are many fresh graduates being hired. While I agree we can train fresh grads to be good developers, it will take time. We need to retain more experienced and talented individuals in TW first. This trend of TW SEA becoming bottom-heavy in terms of experience is getting worrisome for slips in capabilities and quality.

Reviews.Header: Very positive experience, might not be for everyone.
Reviews.Pros: - A very good place to pick up software development best practices. - Lots of amazing colleagues to work with and learn from - Good support available - Various other activities outside the daily work to be a part of - Self-directed learning; your interests at your pace
Reviews.Cons: - If you're someone who needs to be told what to do next, this may not be the place for you. - Work life balance really depends on the project you're on, and your time management.

Reviews.Pros: - The company is huge on continuous learning, people you meet in the company generally will be very driven to learn and grow their skills. This is also supported by the company's dedicated personal budget for learning each employee is entitled to as well as learning platform. - Flat hierarchy - Both senior and junior devs have almost equal standing when it comes to voicing your opinions in team discussions. Junior devs are very much encouraged to be active in technical discussions and get to work closely with clients - You have the freedom and space of what you want to focus on and you'll be supported by your team/company. For example, you can focus more on being Infrastructure Engineer after a period of time focusing on App Development. - Really appreciate the feedback culture in the company - Most teams will practice regular feedback so you'll know where you stand and keep improving. - Some ThoughtWorkers are thought leaders in the industry too, it is very normal to see colleagues speaking at conferences, writing books, etc - Personally find it very inspiring. - The company is also huge and serious in making social impact in the world. There is a dedicated coordinator for all the social initiatives driven by the company, making it easier for employees to be engaged in social initiatives sustainably.
Reviews.Cons: - Since the company is in consulting business, there will be times when you're on the beach (or bench, in general consulting term). During this time, you will not be working on client projects but you're expected to drive your own learning. - Lateral-hire training/onboarding can be better. Felt quite lost when I joined the company at first. And teams are generally working in silos in each client project, so if you're new and has no projects yet, it can be tough to get to know other employees. - Salary-wise is not the highest in the industry. Though there is 13th month bonus, there isn't performance-related bonus.

Reviews.Header: good place for learning, hard to get career progression.
Reviews.Pros: - good learning environment - promotes diversity and inclusiveness - great work life balance
Reviews.Cons: - they are very big on "culture" but if you look deeper, alot of people are just fake and trying to fit in and be what they think the company expects them to be. - difficult to attain career progression as quite flat structured

Reviews.Pros: TW overall is a good company but try to avoid design because of design leaders.
Reviews.Cons: Company says they want to focus and grow the design so they decided to put two head of design for a team of 20 people? which doesn't make any sense. I have been working with them for quite a long time now and I can say both lack design skills and the leader mindset.  All they can do is just one thing... "TALK". Both can't deliver. I doubt if they have ever done any end to end design delivery.  Both head of design behave like mothers "do this, do that". They don't want to give autonomy to the team and want to control everything. Yup almost everything. e.g if both are busy the team gets messages like we can't make it today, let's cancel today's meet. We'll put something new" which never happens. Every team conversation is just about two buzz words, 'Value' and 'Impact' but the team always wonders what exactly does that mean? I bet just like the team they also don't know what both words are and they just use them to show off. It's quite common in the office to use buzz words. Both ladies have two faces. One for TW & SG leadership team and this face is very shiny, everything is going excellent, we are leaders and design is adding tremendous value, another one is with a team which is very dark and scary. There is literally zero team communication which happens because nobody has any interest. Why because both leaders fail to create that environment for the team which TW MD's and HR failed to see and understand.Team feels both are incapable and lousy design leaders. It's just no one wants to talk about this because all they care about is just doing the job and getting a salary. Everyone in the design team is on the verge of leaving TW because of these two. Maybe that's the reason people have started moving out of TW. There are other tons of points but i know nothing will happen because TW MD's will just talk to these two and both are smart enough to cover and brainwash MD's. It's just hopeless. They have decided to hire Sr and Lead designers instead of promoting internally. Why? Because both leaders fail to connect designers/team or mentor designers so that they can grow.  All both care about is their 'own' growth and faking around. Question is who will save TW SG Design team?

Reviews.Header: A good place for a developer to grow
Reviews.Pros: - Very supportive colleagues and working environment. (aka no "jerks" policy) - Work in a team with knowledgable and inspiring technical people, which you can learn new things from - Project teams always carefully crafted to have a higher percentage of seniors and mid level developers as compared to juniors (aka your project will probably go smoothly and no death march) - Deployment of software is always through the automated Continuous Integration/ Deployment pipeline (aka no fear to release new version software, and no staying back late after working hours to fix deployment issue) - Get to be assigned to different projects, which means you get experience in many different languages and technologies to beef up your resume - This is a consulting job, so we have the chance to improve your tech communication skills, as you get to interact with clients (not a job where you just code), which will definitely be valuable in your future career. - There are often office events, and get togethers where we can interact with other teams, (aka: no silos) - Generous salary, and other benefits where the company foots your mobile and internet bill
Reviews.Cons: - Not really a con, but due to the supportive environment, you will not get direct pressure from the higher ups to improve yourself. So over here it is important to plan your career aims and have the self motivation to stick to it. - As your fellow colleagues are always pushing the limit, this is not a place for someone who does not like change or getting out of their comfort zone.

Reviews.Pros: Flat hierarchy Friendly and open culture that is open to help Good software engineering practices
Reviews.Cons: Compensation could have been better

Reviews.Pros: Professionalism and team. Multiple projects to work on
Reviews.Cons: It's a service company- dealing with unhappy clients.

Reviews.Header: Best place to progress in career
Reviews.Pros: - Amazing colleagues, you can learn many things from the people around you. - Project line up is good. - Makes you a better human being by making you think from holistic perspective by internally sharing the news on culture, values, global issues, environment, social and economic issues. - There is a lot of scope to learn new technologies. - Most of the times you'll be pairing with the senior developers, this gives you great opportunities to share your thoughts as well as learn from others. This act of pairing with others expedites your learning.
Reviews.Cons: - Work life balance: In most of the cases, ThoughtWorks takes up very critical and rescue based projects. Because of the nature of the projects, you need to be expert in a technology to solve the issues that occur during the development. And at the same time, it is very difficult, especially in these modern days, to learn many tools and technologies out there in the market. This creates lots of pressure on the developers and makes you to work harder and thus leading to bad work life balance. After you learn these skills in a project you are shifted to another project that demands some other skillsets. For junior developers this is good as they can learn many technologies in their early career. But for mid to senior developers, you'll be constantly (or implicitly) assessed by peers creating lots of pressure to learn lots of tools in a short period of time and you need to prove by delivering the project as well. ThoughtWorks management should understand this situation and should provide right kind of support.

Reviews.Pros: - Well-diverse environment. Different countries, races, religions, genders work together. - Invests a lot in people. They have budget for books and training sessions as well. - Open-minded. Anyone can voice out opinions. - Trust in people. Work timing is generally flexible. - Flat hierarchy. No red-tapes. - True advocate in Agile and Technologies. - Work with the best people. Everyone is friendly as well. - Work in Teams. No one gets left behind. - Plenty of opportunities to travel or get staffed overseas. - Good pantry! ThoughtWorks embrace differences in people.
Reviews.Cons: - Interviews are not easy, especially if you're applying for the tech role - Need to keep learning so as to keep up with the variety of projects available - Tend to always encounter new things, hence there's always a pressure to learn things fast - Sometimes they expect too much out of the people so it might be a little stressful depending on how you take it.

I recalled one of them said “I wanted to be in sales, gain power and money”. Secondly, I joined less than a year, now I’m seeing them chopping off existing headcount, and all hiring freeze. Poor talent retention, and obvious cronyism. Their cloud solution needs tremendous improvement. I’m not surprised looking at their poor cloud penetration and performance. Literally less than 10% of my customers even asking about Oracle Cloud. My friends in the similar industry said the same. Lack of clear and proven strategy. Fire your existing HR TEAM, so the new ones able to find and recruit the right talent. Almost non existence of marketing campaign with clear messaging. Leaders are incompetent. Many are yes man or yes woman. Bring them along to meet customer, they are mumbling gibberish topics. Customers are discombobulated. If any of you thinking of joining them, think twice. Their only hope is the on-premise licenses, unfortunately no one is focusing that. Doom day.

No respect for people's personal time or contributions. Reviews.Header: No worklife balance, appalling workplace bullying, culture of sycophants and yes men.
Reviews.Pros: Compensation and leave policies are good, but you may not be able to take much leave because of heavy workloads.
Reviews.Cons: No worklife balance. Appalling workplace bullying from many quarters including VPs/SVPs in HR, and MD level in some departments. Culture of sycophants and yes men. There is no healthy discussion because people are too afraid to question bad ideas from leaders, so bad ideas from leaders are blindly implemented and not well thought through. Business owners who are not technology professionals are the ones to make decisions about technology investments. If you rightly wouldn't let non-investment professionals make decisions about which financial investments GIC puts money in, why would you let non-tech professionals decide which tech systems GIC buys? Non-tech business owners do not know how to think about tech adoption or how to realise business value from tech. They make ill-considered decisions based on fancy UI and functionality they heard about, and do not consider other important factors such as the capabilities of existing systems which can meet their needs with some reconfiguration/upgrades, the already-fragmented end user experience and lack of time to use more new systems, scalability of the new system, compatibility with other existing systems, post-implementation support and maintenance models/costs, vendor maturity, whether the Tech Department has the right skillsets and capacity to implement and support new systems post go-live. Advice from the Tech Department (to leverage existing systems for example) fall on the deaf ears of business owners who are fixated on launching new systems to boost their careers and meet their personal KPIs. Little to no business value is realised from such new systems which become white elephants with low usage and are decommissioned after just a few years. The hidden costs in terms of time, manpower and money that went into the implementation and post go-live support/maintenance are unjustifiable. At a time when most technologically-mature companies are moving towards tech consolidation, GIC is moving in the opposite direction because business owners making tech investment decisions are not experienced tech professionals, and they do not respect the inputs of the tech SMEs. Imagine if non-investment professionals make decisions about which financial investments to put GIC's money in based on what they feel or hear from their circles or vendors! The country will soon be in financial ruin. Giving non-tech professionals the final say in tech investments is just as bad and a recipe for disaster that has led to a highly fragmented system landscape with multiple overlapping duplicate systems and low user adoption. Even adding head count to the Tech Department requires agreement from the business departments that the manpower costs are charged back to. Since the business departments do not understand the true scope of work and resist when the Tech Department tries to educate them, getting the correct headcount is a struggle and some teams in the Tech Department that directly support the business departments are chronically under-resourced. Unrealistic expectations from business owners about implementation timelines and scope of work exacerbate the problem, leading to burn out and high turnover in the Tech Department, which the outgoing CTO and previous MD of Tech (who left after just 2 years in GIC) 'explained' away as the effect of a good job market. Apparently the job market has been stellar all throughout the pandemic. Leaders at GIC have a tendency to explain away issues so they do not need to have difficult but necessary conversations with their peers in other departments. With new org changes that removed the CTO position, there may be even less Tech influence and representation at the leadership level. The new Tech MD seems nice enough with the right experience ,but has his work cut out for him. Here's hoping he can turn things around.

Reviews.Header: Why I decided to leave Kelly Services
Reviews.Pros: Variable income component that potentially allows employees to make more money.
Reviews.Cons: I'm writing from the perspective of the Singapore office: (1) Lack of opportunities for career advancement (2) Too profts-driven; employees are seen as money-crunching tools (3) Slow payouts system for commissions (4) There doesn't seem to be operating synergies between the head office and its country offices (5) Promotions to senior positions are seemingly not based on merit, but by who's the top sales dog and who's left in the company (6) Non-performing staff are defined too simplistically as people who can't meet sales figures and are often asked to leave It might be interesting for some of you to note that for the time when I was with Kelly Services Singapore, I had one of the highest sales records, and people were talking about promotions etc in line for me; yet when I decided to leave the company and take on an in-house recruiter role, attitudes started changing, and the previous manager I worked for actually had the nerve to say I was asked to leave for non-performance-- a far cry from the truth!

Reviews.Pros: Overall, I have had a positive experience working at this company for the past year. One of the standout features of this company is the open and creative working environment, which has allowed me to feel comfortable and supported in my role. The humane treatment of employees is also a notable aspect of the company culture, as I have always felt valued and appreciated by my colleagues and superiors. The perks and benefits offered by the company, including medical coverage and the option for free food and drinks, are a nice touch and have made my time here more enjoyable. The annual leave policy is reasonable, and the work-life balance has been satisfactory overall especially option to work from home.
Reviews.Cons: One of the drawbacks of working at this company has been the lack of opportunity to work with cutting-edge technologies or on particularly very challenging or very exciting tasks. Additionally, the organization's large size can sometimes make it difficult to keep up with new changes and updates. While the company has a well-established and successful business model, it may not be as dynamic or fast-paced as a startup. Another potential concern for some employees is the company's practice of laying off staff in the event of economic downturns. While this is a common practice in the industry, it can be stressful for those who may be affected. Finally, the system for career growth and advancement within the company can be somewhat complicated, and it may take some time to progress within the organization.

Reviews.Pros: Good employee benefits (Stocks, insurance) Helpful colleagues Good opportunities, quite meritocratic (as long as the higher ups like you.)
Reviews.Cons: Office politics, sometimes subtle but very present. People love to gossip. Saw several reviews about the company being too focused on documentation, and its true. This is a result driven by the SG local Quality. Focuses on the small things, different standard between different individuals (the only reason there is a need to have parent child work instructions is because SG and SD quality probably don't agree on some tiny detail). How to enforce a quality standard when often it is what they perceive? Then only when it fits them they quote some document number. After a while, people get tired and start questioning the need and value of the work they do, time spent on these non value added tasks. So many systems in place, but no one to consolidate, and not enough help and resource given to the sustaining team. And little recognition as well. All these systems basically copy the same data from the same source, and just present it in a different way. All for someone's "project presentation". Constant changes, but not always for the sake of improvement, but to enforce someone's agenda. Yet the top management like to preach about how improvements are important, then go and build a new system instead of improving the older one. Not only that, they want it quickly too. With little to no support. The capable people are over worked, and the mediocre people get to graze and cruise their days away. That is why the turnover rate is so high.

Reviews.Pros: Allows you to be autonomous day to day. Relaxed environment Ok compensation.
Reviews.Cons: Motional was formed by merging several smaller companies. It hasn't reached the point where it's capable of managing those teams and it results in a lot of poor communication, duplicated work, technical debt between team. Given the above it's scaling way too prematurely, increasing its workforce by 50% alone in 2020. this is driven by its obsession with being first to market and a cash pot of 4 billion to back them up. It highly exaggerates what the tech is capable of in its marketing. At times it feels like they're more concerned with perception rather than getting things done. After riding in their vehicles it seems like they have a lot of major hurdles that i personally dont see them overcoming in the next 5 years and yet their marketing always conveys that it's always coming next year. This feeling is shared by people on the ground, working on cars day to day Excessively forcing diversity and inclusion agendas/presentations on its employees which gets annoying quickly. This is coming from a minority. No notice period for firing or resignation Very little company wide policies or documentation. Results in a lot knowledge just being stuck in the heads of individuals that can leave the company in 1 day.

Reviews.Header: Company is becoming better each day.
Reviews.Pros: * Company tries to operate based on the core values. These values help drive the goals/objectives which in turn foster more focused and collective efforts by employees. * Many things are not top-notched but I do see things becoming better each day. * Company is helpful for all kind of work-related visa! * Company seems to have a good relationship with Lyft and Uber.
Reviews.Cons: * For employee who has been with the company longer, maybe it is harder to get significant number of stocks/shares as opposed to someone who just joined that typically get a significant more number of shares in the company. * It can be hard to get green card sponsorship by the company and the HR handling the matter is not the most helpful and approachable. * Company still seems to have a long way to catch up to competitors like Waymo and Cruise. * Company does not have it own ride-hailing app like what Waymo and Cruise are having. Not sure if this will be good or bad in the long run. For now, I feel it could be a potential minor con assuming Waymo and Cruise have better business model.

Reviews.Header: It's a great place to work!
Reviews.Pros: I'll start with mentioning I'm biased because I prefer a start-up culture where there are opportunities to take more initiative and have a greater influence over the end product. Motional definitely allows individuals to take ownership of their work and drive solutions cross-functionally across the organization. The leadership are good at being transparent about issues that we're facing and helping solve challenges head-on rather than shying away. Everyone is very open and supportive. There's a solid culture for working together and helping each other rather than just trying to "climb the corporate ladder".
Reviews.Cons: There are some challenges with overlapping responsibilities and roles across teams. Because every team is empowered to take initiative, many times there are multiple teams that end up working on similar things and duplicating work if they don't coordinate. There's also having "too many cooks in the kitchen". Sometimes many people want to provide their opinion which can inhibit progress from being accomplished. It's nice to have data to make decisions, but sometimes if the data does not exist engineers will struggle to make the best decision possible with the data that is available.

Reviews.Pros: The unlimited PTO seems to actually be unlimited (obviously within reason). I missed a little over a week with an illness within my first 2 months, and it was not an issue at all. I also have a little vacation time off around the Christmas holiday that isn't an issue either, so I'll have used 2 weeks PTO in my first 2 months. Everyone that I've worked with has been friendly and helpful, both within and outside my team. Everyone that I've worked with has also been very knowledgeable on what they are working on.
Reviews.Cons: There's a lack of company process, but that is a common thing with startups. This can be a pro and a con, but I've listed it under cons because Motional is working on a safety critical product in a regulated industry. There does seem to be a good understanding of and reliance on ISO-26262, but there aren't a lot of company processes that define the specific implementation of ISO-26262 that Motional wants to follow.

Reviews.Pros: Good pay, good benefits, downtime, learning new things in an exciting field
Reviews.Cons: Favoritism and politics often decide how far up the ladder you can go and how much you're willing to brown nose etc. Communication between leadership is horrible, some key people have been accused of very inappropriate behavior at the workplace

Reviews.Header: Tons of Inertia - For better or worse
Reviews.Pros: Motional leaders seem to be generally willing to allow contributors to innovate and pursue ideas they find compelling. There is tremendous flexibility and ability to get the job done however the individual sees fit. Surprisingly for a company of its size and with so much influence/investment by major legacy corporations, there is not a lot of needless process and red tape over relatively trivial things. Overall, the attitude seems generally positive, the diversity of people is relatively strong, and the breadth of the company means there is tremendous opportunity for those who wish to find it. The amount of funding Motional has accrued at this point in 2022 has enabled it to become a relatively large company for AV, which even in light of some points of concern instills confidence in the survival of the company for long enough to really begin to truly scale the technology.
Reviews.Cons: Unfortunately, the evolution of Motional as the confluence of several startups and contributions from an automotive OEM and Tier One supplier show...there is a head-scratching amount of work that is lost and redone between product iterations. There are, also, a surprising number of technical capabilities that younger and/or much smaller companies have already attained that Motional has not. A surprisingly dogmatic approach to technology development (ML models for everything!) restricts the pace of advancement and makes for endless headaches on the part of Validation and test teams. Because Motional has only now begun really investing in commercial partnerships (the prior deployment in Las Vegas was really treated as a side show in a lot of ways), it has relatively informal and lax practices and policies around public-facing operations (though, it should be said, not with respect to safety). The extraordinarily conservative nature of the product design (a safety driver AND a safety operator in every vehicle) makes the path to driverless - a goal toward which all AV companies are working - a steep one, even relative to industry peers. The biggest con, in my opinion, is that the lack of structure creates a lot of confusion and churn, and then an incredible amount of duplicated work. It also leads to strained relationships across functions, when the work one group does is not adequately communicated to another, and then priorities/work/finished product conflicts.

Reviews.Header: Suitable for a select few, Worst company to work for for the rest
Reviews.Pros: Brand name, work with smart individuals Acceptable compensation and benefits Good entry to middle level management
Reviews.Cons: Hire quick, fired fast without thinking of repercussions As an HR with over 10 years of experience, having worked a or supported a complex and diverse mix of organisations, this company is by far the worst and most messy organisation I have encounter - extremely bureaucratic and political - lacks transparency and all decision made from top management or a select few (usually c-levels) - zero sense of job security and extremely long working hours - everyone works for themselves - people who gets in early gets to stay people who gets in late gets the cut first - A company that lacks focus Perhaps by no fault of its own, it is a business to have yet to establish a sustainable business model Remote work and decentralised setting removes the sense of a company, team culture and brand identity No one whom I have spoke and work with in this company is truly happy and excited to be here

Reviews.Header: An almost incredible experience and dream job
Reviews.Pros: To clarify first, yes I was affected by the layoff, and I should had probably given my feedback whilst in the company but this is for jobseekers. Competitive payout for sales and they do constant review on this which is fantastic. Flexible dress code, Flexible hours( of course with you meeting KPI), Good benefits (AL, food voucher & transport allowance) and i truly believe the Founders are nice, trusting(maybe too much) and sincere even though I see some negative reviews on them here. Truthfully, the company was INCREDIBLE for any hungry sales associate when I first joined, they allowed us to acquire merchants from broad categories while recognising renewal sales from merchants we close, everyday I was excited to wake up looking forward to work ( how many can really say that in their job) to build carousell whilst helping merchants build their business growth with carousell and of course growing my paycheque! It was a dream job! With this system it was almost like i was running my own business and i look forward to close new merchants and renewing them showing them growth on their business. I wanted to stay here till retirement.
Reviews.Cons: Just too much went wrong so instead of typing them all out, i advise job seekers must be Extremely adaptable and okay with unfair KPI distribution and non thoroughly thought out major implementations… otherwise take a chance and cross your fingers for the higher end treatment due to negligence in target allocation and expectation. Still a 4 star cause i know founders are trying their best, just unfortunate they hired the wrong management. I truly feel sad.

Reviews.Header: Really great company to work for
Reviews.Pros: This is the best company I have ever worked for. I joined the company around 2.5 year ago. I have a really great work-life balance while working here. I got married after a few months joining Carousell and I got a baby girl about a year ago. I was able to spent a lot of time with my family and my working hours has been very flexible. I would say I spent quite a lot of time during the day taking care and playing with my daughter and I work mostly when she is sleeping. Really good managers. I think I was quite lucky to have a chance to work with very good managers. They gave me advices and opportunities to advance within the company. We have 1 on 1 regularly and generally we discuss about what I want to archive in my career and how to get there. Excellent team and really smart people. Most people that I worked with at Carousell are very humble and open-mined, making it very easy for the team to discuss conflicting ideas and come up with good solutions. The Carousell business is doing very well as well.
Reviews.Cons: - No dental benefit - The interviewing process can be quite long

Reviews.Pros: - Culture is good - People are nice - Increase salaries when they see they are paying less than industry standards
Reviews.Cons: I hope this review helps you decide whether to join the company or not - Leadership team is inconsistent (leaders quit quite often) and is of not top-notch quality except 1-2 folks. You can figure out the kind of questions they ask in meetings, which totally shows they have no experience in this domain - Ask your HM during the interview, what is the companies strategy, what's the long-term plan. One day they want to become e-commerce for second-hand goods and another day they want to focus on 10 other items - Old employees/leaders play politics - They increase salaries to retain employees (Attrition is always high here) but have no processes, structure in design, engineering, data, product - Company is 9 years old still extremely chaotic, with no processes, no structure, and also growth has been slow. Look at their peers which have grown significantly big - Leaders do mistakes and don't accept them which is horrible - No focus on employee growth/career growth framework Join the company if you - - Want to work in a startup that is still finding its overall strategy and is chaotic (okay with high attrition) - Believe in their vision - Talk to 4-5 ex-employees of your department and if you're convinced with their feedback then only join Lot of good reviews on glassdoor surprize vs conversation I have with employees internally

Reviews.Cons: Not really a con but here there’s no AWS or PB so how serious people take performance appraisals is sorely based on how much they still care to improve. Tech wise, they use GCP instead of AWS (like i said there’s no AWS :p) so it might take sometime to get used to for the folks in the AWS camp. There’s a lot of deprecated and poorly documented/hard to understand code because there’s no hard requirements on code standards. It makes people whom these code are handed over to miserable because they’re afraid to break things if they refactor. In general, very little best practices can been seen here, eg people commit large PRs expecting colleagues to review instead of doing a stacked PR, no formatting checks in auto test etc. It’s hard to push for a change in tech culture because the seniors are resistant. Then again, I guess all these are understandable because it’s not a tech company.

Reviews.Header: Strategy is a mess, directionless leadership
Reviews.Pros: You can have a lot of ownership depending on the team and role. Culture depends on the team. Compensation and benefits are ok.
Reviews.Cons: Carousell has lost its way. They are trying to do too many things at the same time. Leadership is clueless on the right direction. There are competitors everywhere and it won't be long before they are under extreme pressure. Growth has slowed down and the product has suffered. Leadership keeps talking about using data but only when you have an idea, otherwise data doesn't matter when they want to do something. Innovation has suffered as a result and you can see that in the product. Very slow vs. other tech companies. Join if you are in the early stages of your career to learn some good processes and make some good friends. For senior people, stay away. Lot of people have left and they don't have any idea how to retain the others.

Reviews.Header: Please consider these points before joining
Reviews.Pros: 1. Most of the employees here came from worse working environments e.g. Media agencies, toxic local SMEs, Honestbee and hence believe that this grass is a lot greener. If you’ve been through terrible work environments, yes carousell will be (slightly) better. Is it the best place to work in Singapore? Definitely not. 2. There is autonomy to make decisions that have immediate outcomes and visibility, and on some occasions the founders will be verbally grateful to you for them. 3. Most people on the ground here are really trying their best to do what they love and work hard. And yes, if you are looking to join the marketplace experience team, or the tech team - you are most likely to enjoy your experience there. Carousell understands that tech is competitive and will do their best to treat tech hires right, not so much for the other departments. 4. In some departments, there’s a good culture of fun and team bonding. Carousell is intentional about spending time together and bonding, and there will be budget for this too.
Reviews.Cons: 1. The Carousell group acquired 4 companies over the years - OLX (Philippines), Mudah (Malaysia), Chotot (Vietnam) and OneKyat (Myanmar). There is a lot of mess and neglect in this process and the founders are struggling to understand how to manage them, most people here complain of being overworked, underpaid and under-supported way more than their Carousell counterparts. 2. Management - the Glassdoor reviews that you read here are true. Even though most of management came from affluent and long standing histories of experience, most of them just want to oppress their reports. They know nothing and want to be treated like royalty - you will be asked to book meeting rooms for them, teach them how to record on zoom/order food on foodpanda, buy things for them and much more. (To be fair, most of the things experienced are in the People team - high turnover rate a clue?) You will be shocked at how they can say words with no accountability and tact, despite their “experience”. The founders are much younger than most and clearly struggle to manage them - all these incidents mentioned were bought up to the founders and no action taken, resulting in employees resigning because they gave up hope. 3. As much as they seem to look corporate and SME-like, most people here will admit that it’s still very much like a start up. Little to no processes, constant change in systems and poor communication downstream. 4. There is a deep systemic resentment towards salary. The context is as a startup, most employees who have been there for years received start up pay. Only up till a year ago, the management decided to pay competitively to new hires and that’s when the bitterness and comparison arose. Imagine only getting half or less of the salary of your counterpart and doing the exact same work - as much as this is common, Carousell is not an MNC and it doesn’t come with any MNC benefits. 5. Burnout culture: is real here. As much as the people experience team tries to sell “work life balance” and “Wellness Wednesdays”, they don’t actually live it out themselves. You will see the team reply to slack or send emails at 12am-1am, people are angry and uncooperative and being told they lack resilience when they are being pushed to breaking point at work. There is deep mistrust for managers as most of them are deemed inexperienced or incompetent. The people team try to mitigate but everyone can tell that they are struggling with their own manager, too. When asked, most of them are on the lookout for better opportunities and said that they will leave in a heartbeat if the opportunity presents itself.

Reviews.Header: Manager have no clue on how to run a company.
Reviews.Pros: No dress code and nice office
Reviews.Cons: Culture: Management like to talk about how important they put people first. FYI the ‘people’ is the founders, management and ppl they like. Founders like to appear and talk during townhall, but when it comes to execution it is zero. Hiring the wrong people to do the wrong thing. - Do note that a lot of ppl they hire are ahbeng and ahlian that cant even speak properly. Most management are uncle aunty that have load of experience but have no clue how the tech and marketplace works. Company still not profitable. - Imagine in the market for 10y and still losing money, this tells you how bad the company is doing. A lot of the verticals are still losing money until today. Since management are bunch or uncle and aunty, their idea of making money is to increase price of their subscription and ads for those verticals that are doing well. Toxic Culture - lots of politics in the company always regarding who the management likes and dislikes. For a company that is not profitable to have too many managers within a department. A lot of the associates they hire are ex-colleagues of the manages, and managers will prioritise these colleagues in terms of job assignment and promotion. Incompetent staff - a lot of their managers are too incompetent. Asked their project manager a question and took him 2 weeks to answer me. He will organise a Q&A session with us, but its all questions since he cant answer us and can only note down those questions we asked and nvr answer us. Founder is not taking this seriously. They will come in office and chitchat with everyone like they are close friends. Talk like Steve Jobs during meeting and town halls but no have idea on execution and neither do they care.

Reviews.Header: Not a great place to work
Reviews.Pros: They have flexible hours to work and inter-team mobility is available after a while. Talented teammates.
Reviews.Cons: - Culture: They talk pretty highly of their core values, but once it trickles down to following them, it's no where close. - Management: What they say is always right and they favor their own references and ex-colleagues when it comes down "trust". Personally, they don't treat HR folks as a business too so, HR opinion is the last opinion or better still "no opinion required" category. Highly bureaucratic/ political and very traditional in their approach and highly judgemental as leaders. - Attrition: a pretty high double figure attrition and a lot of people have left in HR /Tech/ product teams, clearly because they felt less heard or the leaders didn't work too hard to retain talent. Try avoiding - Interview process: is long, very long, very very long. They want to compete with FAANG company process but pay you peanuts in salary. They are always depending over budgets. People team and TA team have maximum attrition this year, they say "i hear you" and ask you to move on. very insensitive even though they pretend to sound concerned and neglect you after sharing concerns. Overall as an organisation, the co-founders pop up during townhalls to talk about company performance but very less invested in people and they go quiet on decisions for people. They may hear you out but they don't care to action out probably max assign your managers to deal with your issues. In that matter, none of the management really cares to hear about your concerns, it's too fake to be honest. So unless, you are a reference or you know some leaders well - you are bound to grow slowly in this space, highly biased in decisions and very likely to hear you out but not provide any solution or leave it to the managers to take biased decisions. P.s. Carousell is more responsive on glassdoor than actually solving problems internally.

Reviews.Pros: Recommended for Indian India origin. 90% are of indian origin. Eg out of a dept of 180 around 90%are indian. Let's not forget there are other departments too. The other dept too are dominated by Indian. It is very normal to see a reporting structure of up to two or three level of indian mgm before reaching the french mgm. It is very safe for indians as they tend to work behind the door, indian style of management. You will fit very well if you are indian.
Reviews.Cons: If you are non Indian, it could be discouraging. As the culture is heavily leaning towards Indian culture, it easy to face racism, or simply lack of trust among the indian and non-Indian. Not surprising. Important roles or task usually heavily filtered despite how good you are. They tend to hire their own ppl for important task. Non indian will be filtered for low priority tasks. The rest of the non-Indian roles are more more to fill up the quota. But, indian are almost 90% , strange. Does they ever follow the quota? As you 3ill be working with mostly indian hired contract staff, the staff holds onto information due to insecurity. Be prepare that you will be celebrating Indian festive more than any of the national celebration.

Reviews.Pros: Can leave work on time Lots of annual leave System is fast Dual monitors in office

Yet when they hire new staff, they earn more than current staff. It just feels like a KYC factory here. No one cares how u feel or how u are coping. Just do files until u drop dead from exhaustion. Senior management has no KYC experience so they have absolutely no idea on what’s happening on the ground Need to work in office during pandemic even though the job is 95% individual based and requires very little interaction with other colleagues. Now with pandemic over, everyone is 100% working in office. And nobody bothers to ask us if we are ok with coming back to office. We are just told to do so. Turnover rate here very high. People leave after 6 months or less. On the other end, those who can’t find opportunities elsewhere are stuck here for years

Reviews.Pros: • The work is not challenging so you will have more time to focus on other outside activities, like finding a better job. • Lots of foreign employees.
Reviews.Cons: • I had the most toxic and most political managers in my entire work experience. Managers with no humanity will pull you down themselves if they don't like you. • Promotion and salary increase are not output-based or skill-based, but your likability on the perspective of French management. You will witness management favorites get promoted while excellent and hard-working employees who are doing the real work get neglected with measly increase. Performing in year end parties or organizing department outings will give you more chance to be promoted than doing the actual work. • The management is rude to the core and find pleasure in lowering the morale of employees. You will witness managers being racists, making fun of foreign employees' accent, bad-mouthing co-workers, employees who are resigning or resigned, and even counterparts in Paris/overseas. Rude managers will sometimes speak in their native language during meetings to avoid other attendees from participating in the discussion. • In summary, I have a horrible experience working with CACIB.

Reviews.Pros: Good learning environment. Things are changing everyday so you get to learn new things everyday too. Perks are good, company generally care for its employees. But lack of experience in managing a rapidly growing company. There are opportunities for direct access to senior leaders. E.g senior leaders bother to turn up for presentations.
Reviews.Cons: Team in BKK are not as experienced and smart. A Thai director can’t even write an email in proper English, makes me wonder how she is promoted. Team compete against team to outshine each other instead of collaborating together. Promotions come if you are vocal enough. Some processes are very backward and require streamlining.

Reviews.Pros: At least some friendly colleagues around.

Reviews.Pros: Company was amazing, benefit was good, salary was ok.
Reviews.Cons: Super Stressful work, very toxic

Reviews.Pros: 5 stars for the company overall Good international environment where you have interdepartmental colleagues from all over the world Pre covid there was monthly pantry mini parties to celebrate birthdays every month, with buffet and emcee and fun. Singapore office located in CBD very convenient with lots of f&b options Two very nice pantries! Office very well renovated Fair remuneration MNC efficiency e.g smooth onboarding and staff administration
Reviews.Cons: 1 star experience only at the Singapore customer service department. Kindergarten style of management. If you need to go toilet when it's not your fixed break timing, please inform the class monitor or teacher. Micromanagement If you need to go to toilet beyond an arbitrary "reasonable timing", be prepared to be questioned. Office politics. To be fair this happens everywhere, but I was very surprised it happens in a call center because other call centers are well known to be free of politics at agent level at least. Was pretty glaring too. Like I said it happens everywhere, even in schools, just like in school, where you have teacher's pet and the rest. Extreme high turnover rate gives clues about the environment. Vast majority of agents do not stay beyond 2 to 3 years, those who can stay 1 year and longer are considered seniors. Most leave in a matter of weeks or months, you see people come and go all the time. People leave due to high work stress (not easy to meet the kpi and multitasking, work processes are also tedious and everchanging) and on top of that still need to deal with people issues aka office politics. In other call centers you see people staying for decades. Not much leeway for keen new agents who are late bloomers or need more time to cope with the steep learning curve, as it's very stats oriented. Management critical of agents but don't apply the same level of standards to themselves. Give just 1 example, it is only fair to be punctual yourself before you criticise others for lateness. Rules not equally applied, most glaring example is with regards to usage of handphone at workstation.

Reviews.Header: World class talent but has gone too fat to move fast
Reviews.Pros: - Working with world-class talent - Great culture - Many Stripes I met are the kindest people I ever know
Reviews.Cons: - Heavy emphasis on docs culture and process which contributes to moving slow - Development tooling can't keep up with the growth of headcount within tech org, it's hard to make simple changes

Reviews.Pros: - Pay is above average. - IPO possible in 2023 - Products are innovative - Great brand recognition globally.
Reviews.Cons: - Leadership team is toxic, creates a culture of fear among employees - Targets are not consistent among reps, based on favoritism and not when you join the organization - Reps are not collaborative and extremely competitive with each other - Not invested into culture at all, they are merely there for optics purposes - Middle management in regional offices sometimes have no experience in management. - Internal process are a joke, alot of the sales teams still use excel. - Extremely budget conscious with team building or general team outings. - Alot of the employees are arrogant and do not want their peers to succeed. - Constantly changing strategy on which markets to enter and pull out from - Overall disingenuous and fake vibes - No empathy for overall well being

Reviews.Pros: Great people that are all generally very supportive and genuinely interested in your ideas and success. Encouragement and positivity are pretty widespread.
Reviews.Cons: Promotion process is in my experience is extremely opaque and is mgr/mgr's mgr driven and your directly involvement/influence over it is negligible. Being in Singapore has directly held me back from promotion due to decision makers being located in the US. Prioritisation and decision making is probably the two biggest things holding Stripe back. Its difficult to prioritise as an IC because leaders don't give you a good idea or help on what should be prioritised. Because of this there's a seemingly endless number of projects people are spending (and often wasting) their time on because no one effectively tells people they need to not prioritise it. Its widespread and pervasive. Decision making its the weakest point. Simple decisions (i.e. decisions on things that have low risks and can very easily be undone) takes ages to decide on.

Reviews.Header: Great outlook for the company, weak trajectory for APAC

Reviews.Pros: Interesting, meaningful work. Talented colleagues.

Reviews.Header: Poor leadership and lack of direction
Reviews.Pros: Some of the brightest and most empathetic people I've met are from Stripe.
Reviews.Cons: Poor leadership; The leadership team has no direction, and have changed the company focus multiple times within a year. For a company that prides itself on being transparent, management has restricted the amount of information that is shared with the ground staff. Massive overhiring in 2022 has led to much redundancy and the recent lay-offs in November 2022, yet in October 2022, management is still convincing everyone that the hiring is justified and outlook is strong. Completely do not recommend this company;

Reviews.Cons: Being in Ops, I feel undervalued at Stripe often and we often don't get the common benefits that other teams have like off-sites etc. I work every weekend and I feel the pressure to not be able to take PTO off even when I have them as coverage would be an issue, even more so with a very lean team. Career progression is also difficult.

Reviews.Header: Perfect place for workaholic looking for challenges
Reviews.Pros: -People are nice and smart here to work with -Business is thriving with solid product and reputation -Pay is on the upper side of the market with attractive RSU -Awesome transparency and documentation
Reviews.Cons: -You are expected to work until the bone, weekends work and nighttime calls are expected, definitely not a place to work if you want to have a work-life balance and you have a family, especially for Singapore. High tendency to burn out. -The processes are broken and always changing, since this role is developing, you are expected to wear A LOT of hats and to deliver A LOT of things in a short period of time, without a clear definition of who does what. It is a startup culture in enterprise organisation scale hence expect chaos. -Underinvested and limited career opportunities/development especially for a non-developer or technical role. -The reason people stay is because of RSU. Many people will join here to get the jump in salary and branding in CV for their next opportunity.

Reviews.Pros: Strong mission, vision, culture and benefits to employees

Reviews.Pros: + everyone is smart, down-to-earth, and genuinely cares about users + leaders have good vision and clear direction for the company + Stripe managers really impress me, most of them is truly people manager that cares about you.
Reviews.Cons: - we're growing too fast, new org leader bring culture from previous company - everyone is extremely stretch and busy. a lot of team is underresources to do anything - we're functioning more like a corporate vs a startup. everything need to have a business plan for years ahead and business case for prioritization. it used to be more agile and adaptable.

Reviews.Pros: Many exciting things happening as the company grows. Lots of opportunities to be exposed to interesting new verticals. People are friendly.

Reviews.Cons: Still can feel a bit under-resourced the farther you get from HQ. Not for everyone - if your someone who wants a cookie-cutter, predictable job, this place isn't for you. You'll be expected to challenge the status quo. High bar for written communication.

Reviews.Header: Middle Management have minimal experience and training.
Reviews.Pros: Great office environment Humble and friendly people all around Awesome medical and work/life benefits
Reviews.Cons: Ineffective and inexperience managers: I have seen many people managers promoted into their roles without any real training or prior experience at all. People management involves being responsible for the growth, wellbeing and career trajectories of actual human beings, Too many junior managers at Stripe simply given the role of managing a team without having any clue what they are supposed to do on a day to day basis. This results in ALOT of unnecessary attrition of otherwise good talent which I have personally witnessed. Not enough emphasis and importance placed on the growth of APAC offices, product localisation, new market launches, local pain points and talent development are often overlooked/deprioritised and severe lack of internal mobility that is otherwise seen in the US/EMEA offices.
