Reviews.Pros: A good place to work for.
Reviews.Cons: A lot of thing changes everytime.

Reviews.Header: Overworked, very little diversity in eng org, but hopefully big pay off
Reviews.Pros: The work is very high impact and there are lots of opportunities to learn if you're not already familiar with the fintech space. Most of the big projects I've been on so far have been fun to work on. There are also a lot of talented, kind, and helpful engineers at Stripe who are really nice to learn from. I really enjoy my manager and the folks on my team. The money + bonuses are ~ok~. Pretty standard for a pre-IPO unicorn, but the goal is that there will be a big pay off later (fingers crossed).
Reviews.Cons: - The work life balance is *bad*. For how many products Stripe has, we are a very lean company. Too lean. There's just a lot of work, and very very tight deadlines, very fast paced, and not enough engineers and product managers to do all of it. If you want WLB as an engineer, join an infrastructure team, not a product team. - There is little to no investment in making the engineering org more diverse. This was surprising to me because of a lot of public facing company statements, but don't be fooled like I was. People (at least in the eng org) do not care about diversity. - HR sucks. And of course they would, I guess. But I had a really negative experience with HR where I walked away feeling completely devalued and gaslit. - Dev environments kinda suck and make the work a lot slower than it should be.

Reviews.Pros: The pay is good because otherwise they can't get people
Reviews.Cons: I decided to share my experience within the organisation. My time at Stripe is a place with an unhealthy culture. First, most people who work at Stripe hate it and verbally say that. However, Stripe pays a lot, and that is a reason for people to stay. I remember a recruiter telling me a Stripe is one of the best-paying companies. If another company pays more, they have a boring product or a terrible culture. Stripe has to spend a lot as well because the culture is toxic. There is a culture of selfishness, intimidation and creating fear to let people do what they want. I tried to contact HR to share my story in multiple situations, but they didn't want that. They point you to the virtual door. At this time, when you experience inappropriate behaviour, HR should listen to you; however, in my case, that did not happen. I understand that money is, to most people, a big driver, but Stripe is not worth it. They have a high turnover rate, and this is because of the culture in the organisation. I know many people who started working after I left the organisation, and they all say it was one of there worst experiences in their working career.

Reviews.Header: Worst company in my life; they treat you like robots who only care about money
Reviews.Pros: The pay is good. Their equity is finally worth something.
Reviews.Cons: Senior management does not seem to know that their employees are humans, not robots. In this company and on my team, there's hardly any team activity, chit-chat, social activity, team building, lunch/dinner, etc. Most teams in the company are distributed but managers are not trained nor capable of managing remote employees. Hence, people in this company don't talk to each other casually that much. They are like work robots who only communicate for work. Slack is work and work only. The company doesn't invest in any social activities like Christmas party. I am not saying that I love corporate events. But there is zero... Hence, people just turn on their company at 9am, work on their laptop and never talk to each other like humans do. Employees have very weak personal relationships with each other. It's soul crushing. The only thing they offer is equity, which is a golden handcuff. They don't offer you cash raises that much during performance reviews. If you perform well, you get these equity grants in March which only start vesting quarterly from August (5 months later). That's their way to trap you in this awful environment for longer. The CEO loves Amazon. I suppose that's why they created this Amazon-like fear-driven environment. People are afraid to speak up. They don't dare to challenge their boss. They do whatever their boss says, until all of a sudden, their bosses are let go without notice. They actively manage people out even though sometimes our systems, onboarding and environment didn't allow employees to succeed. Employees are just let go without notice. You will often here "today is XXX's last day / last Friday was their last day". It's like a zombie movie. In employee survey, lots of people indicate that they don't want to stay in the company for more than 1-2 years and they don't feel like there is any career growth. But management never addressed them or tried to do anything to change it. When they talk about "culture", it's about "productivity and efficiency". Stripe only hires people who've been doing a similar job for many years. Therefore, people can't easily move internally to try something different. Leadership doesn't invest in or sponsor any DEIB activities. A lot of employees are not happy that they did a private equity raise instead of IPO, which would have likely set us at a higher valuation. If you're a productive and soulless robot who loves being tied to a golden handcuff while working on a payment software seeing your coworkers disappear randomly, this is the place for you to work.

Reviews.Header: Great company, great benefits, good company culture
Reviews.Pros: This was my first job after college. I had the best manager and really good team. Competition is in the nature of a sales role but still we were a strong team. Realistic targets. Everyone is always open to help and there was a 1 month long training when I first started. Afterwards, when I wasn't performing great they offered to give me another 1 month training instead of firing me. They definitely don't hire people to fire.
Reviews.Cons: Nothing bad to say. This was a great experience. Sales was not for me.

Reviews.Header: Fast paced, lots to learn but as expected
Reviews.Pros: Salary - The pay is really good and stacks up well against the market. People - Stripe hires smart, competent people, often from different background from what you might typically find in the tech world. Food - It baffles me that some reviewers put this in the con section. It's free food. Honestly, what do some people think they are owed? Management - My direct line manager is great and anyone I have encountered has also been very competent. No complaints here. Vision - The Collison bros are obviously extremely smart individuals with a great vision for the product. I feel comfortable with them at the helm.
Reviews.Cons: Career Progression - No clear pathway for new starters to get promoted. People who join Stripe often stay here for a while, probably waiting for the IPO pay day. This means in periods of slow growth, like the one we are currently in, it can be difficult to see where the next step forward is. Messy Processes - Stripe has grown so fast that they have struggled to bring their processes up to speed in tandem. It can be difficult to get easy things done. Thankfully, they are aware of the issue and are attempting to resolve it. Overworked - Can't speak to this from a personal viewpoint but I do get the feeling that Stripe is understaffed and overworked in many key departments which is causing a lot of stress.

Reviews.Pros: - Smart/Intelligent people - Innovative/Creative - Pushes employees to work smart and elevate work ethic - Kind and thoughtful people - Culture encourages empathy - Close to IPO - Brand name company - Thoughtful layoff approach - Thoughtful communication style
Reviews.Cons: - Chaotic - SUPER POLITICAL - No work-life blend - A lot of management should be managed out - Clique-y - Perf/talent review process is unreasonable - Poor recognition - Hustle culture - Lack of employee appreciation - Everyone is really burnt out

Reviews.Header: There was opportunity until there wasn't
Reviews.Pros: Good people to work with, employee perks are often good too. Steep initial learning curve about payments and fintech which was good when starting.
Reviews.Cons: No progression opportunities from SDR - not looking like this will change anytime soon given the current economy Poor management and communication - numerous attempts to pull the wool over SDR eyes by promising things (e.g. promotion in a year), not delivering and then changing the narrative (you can promote in 18-24 months). Sales education is subpar - team mostly gets by because the power of Stripe brand in the market. Spray and pray emailing is common. Targets keep increasing as opposed to reflecting the economic environment around us. Pay varies wildly with the more senior and longer running SDRs actually earning MUCH LESS than the newer hires - I've heard of one SDR earning around 60k OTE and another 75k (the pay difference for the same work is disgusting)

Reviews.Pros: good food good people smart people
Reviews.Cons: lots of work too much work

Reviews.Pros: The benefits, perks and compensation were outstanding and well above average.
Reviews.Cons: My direct team were supportive and like family anything outside of that we/the "diverse" were treated like outsiders --there was little to no "inclusion".

Reviews.Pros: Hard-working, kind colleagues; successful and valuable product; lots of learning on the job
Reviews.Cons: Leadership makes decisions without fully considering the employee experience, tons of thrash, no real commitment to DEI or internal pay equity, founders are brilliant but have major blind spots when it comes to creating a culture of trust and safety - have given this topic lip service but done nothing to change it; burnout culture.

Reviews.Pros: -Excellent pay -Many other people who work there are nice and trying desperately to look out for one another
Reviews.Cons: -Every decision made at Stripe is done so in a desperate, terrified bid to avoid the CEO's disapproval. That is it. That is the sole cultural center of Stripe. -Individualist, often offensive, seemingly misogynistic CEO surrounded by "yes" people with not a single soul in leadership willing to call him out. -Messy messy messy. Internal processes, internal communications, internal organization, policies, procedures, etc. either don't exist or are impossible to track down and understand. A shiny exterior, but inside the employee experience is nearly impossible to navigate. -There is one specific type of worker who can thrive at Stripe. And if you have any cares in the world outside of looking like a producer at work (read: family, hobbies, children, morals, etc.), you don't fit the bill, and you will feel bad every day.

Reviews.Pros: Pay, work flexibility (location, hours), training and onboarding is amazing, mac environment, health insurance is really good, monthly wellness stipend was good.
Reviews.Cons: I was at Stripe (I made a career change) for less than a year before I was laid off, so it's difficult to find another similar role with little experience. It seems as if company culture can be immature, I've had coworkers randomly let go without warning, prior to layoffs.

Reviews.Header: Solid teammates, but expect to work weekends
Reviews.Pros: -Eng team was extremely impressive and took on a lot of ownership including writing PRDs -very data driven, lots of analyses -People in general were very sharp
Reviews.Cons: -WLB: even though my manager told me working weekends wasn't expected, many people did which felt like it was expected -product intuition driven culture vs. experiments driven -product team lacked resources and wasn't clear when hires would happen

Reviews.Pros: High potential for growth Cool projects to work on Leader in its field Great (in-office) perks Great brand name to get on your resume
Reviews.Cons: Sales people are treated as the second class citizens of Stripe: - A special equity bonus program was rolled out to the whole company except sales people. Why? We just heard it's "too complicated" to set this up for sales people who are on variable commissions. - You don't get paid on new products you sell. Stripe launches new products all the time. Even though you're expected to learn, promote, and sell these products, you won't get paid until the comp team gets around to figuring this out which could take 6 months or longer. - Very little support offered to closers. AEs are expected to do a lot of their own prospecting. The outbound org is still very undeveloped. - Same goes for post-signed support. No clean breaks. Even if you attach a support package to your deal, you'll find yourself continuing to work with that company well after you close the deal. - You spend less time selling and more time working in tickets given the complexity of deals at Stripe. - Really bad sales incentives compared to other high growth sales organizations. Lengthy commission cycles that lack transparency, little to no spiffs (the few I've seen are paltry), although we did just get accelerators! Hell will freeze over before Stripe offers a Prez Club. The equity bonus program mentioned above was the biggest slap in the face.

Reviews.Pros: - compensation is ok but coming down
Reviews.Cons: - work nonstop including weekends - too much reporting including what you did each day - cost cutting. Growth is gone.

Reviews.Pros: Your resume probably would have one of the strongest impression for working at Apple. The role will be challenging but therefore you will definitely be good at what you are doing. The people you meet are phenomenal and unbelievably intelligent. You talk to 5 people with one problem and they each give you different solution, but all of them are essential and right for the customer.
Reviews.Cons: I found the pay to be a bit low for the skillset/commitment required by the employee. You will need to admit the fact that you are in the support team after all and therefore you really need to sprint to build your asset; because you will not learn how to code like an engineer, how to sell like a seller, or how to be educated in finance/logistics/procurement/etc. Your tools for success will be the tools developed for the company, or the stakeholder relationships you have built. You are really on your own when it comes to building your career path. With that said, you will get to work with many departments (mentioned above). As a member of a centralized team, you are responsible for coming up with what top-notch service you can bring to the customers and internal stakeholders. You will be responsible for your own career. It is not recommended if you are type of person who is looking to work in an easy environment where you don't have to work hard but still get paid because you work for a tech giant.

Reviews.Pros: Environment, 100% remote, and above market wage offer

Reviews.Pros: - A mission that matters - Opportunity to make an impact - Flexible hours - Can work from home - Good work-life balance - Fun colleagues - 5 weeks of paid time off (including the "me" days) - 16 weeks of maternity and paternity leave - Annual company party in June in Estonia (Summer Days)
Reviews.Cons: - You might not get the stock options you've been promised. The stock option process is that your manager has 10 days at the beginning of the quarter to start the stock option grant process and get it approved by specific people. If anyone doesn't approve it for any reason (sick, off, forgot), you don't get your stock grant and need to wait for the next quarter. The number of the stock options in your grant depends on the stock price of the previous quarter. The stock price has doubled in the past 3 months, so employees who didn't get their stock options grant approved in time last month will get half the number of the stock options they were promised, in addition to not receiving stock options this quarter. Because of this, a fair number of people lost dozens of thousands of dollars. When this happens, no one will let you know that you're not getting your stock options. If you ask, the company will let you know that this is the company policy and that they have planned to change the way stock option grants work. It's been one year that the stock option grants are supposed to change in 2 quarters. It's still supposed to change in 2 quarters. - Each team gets the same budget for the pay increases (percentage-wise) and the team impact and performance doesn't matter. - A lot of smart people left. There are more and more employees who don't care about making an impact. - There are more and more dumb company policies and it's getting harder to challenge them but most people don't care. It's a bit like what you would see in a bank.

Reviews.Pros: Great culture and good benefits

Reviews.Header: Be cautious joining a regional expansions team in Singapore
Reviews.Pros: - People you work with in Singapore office are generally pleasant - Product you work on does help people. It doesnt help people the best, but it does help.
Reviews.Cons: I want to stress cons here are only relevant for regional expansions teams in Singapore. There are other teams not suffering from these problems, they are pretty ok, not FAANG ok but ok for the tier Wise is in. - Your work is highly derivative. Product and engineering leadership in this office do not believe in building/owning anything new, nor do they believe in localising the product better. As a result, a large portion of your work revolves around adapting something built explicitly for Europe (but said to be "generic") to Asian market. It is simply very boring work on archaic tech stack. - Your hours can be very long. Something is constantly on fire and your regular workload isnt exactly light already. I found myself constantly shifting gear from 120% to 150%, never getting a break. You need to work with a lot of people in EU timezone on services you do not own to get anything done and they will not accommodate you. The result is a lot of compulsory work in your evening. In the entirety of the company (which is not bad frankly for engineers), you will find regional expansions team's long hour vs uninspiring work produces the worst payoff for your perf and learning.

Reviews.Pros: Good work culture and people

Reviews.Header: Love the company but hate my current role
Reviews.Pros: - Great product that is founded on Robin Hood like ethos. - Great work-life balance as a CS associate on the ground. I literally don't have to worry about bringing work home once my shift is over, and management does not force you to do overtime work if you're not up for it. - For a CS role that doesn't require tech skills, the entry level pay is one of the best I've had. - Barely any office politics to navigate. When there is an issue that needs escalation, there is no finger pointing and the discussion is always about how to fix the issue first. - Side projects are available on an application basis, so that CS agents can work with another non-CS team on improving the product based on their insights working on the ground.
Reviews.Cons: - Product is expanding faster than the rate of hiring. There have been several crises that have caused customer contacts to balloon, but management have only come up with stop gap measures each time. They have not been able to come up with solutions that systemically fix the issues that cause CS agents to be overwhelmed. - In terms of treating employees, it feels like Wise is more interested in rigidly equal treatment rather than *equitable* treatment. Leads don't seem interested in making case-by-case concessions for staff who may need more support than others, on the rationale that "if we make an exception for you, everyone else will start asking for exceptions". - Unless you are intending to become a CS Team Lead, the career progression in CS is rubbish. Appraisals leading to pay increments are only conducted once a year after winter regardless of join date, for a mere two hundred dollars increment. Also, the leads seem more interested in keeping you in their team for as long as possible (so as to avoid frequent turnover) and don't actively look out for opportunities for you to transit to other teams unless you ask for it. - Workforce management has a tendency of making sweeping and knee jerk changes to how CS agents work based on productivity statistics alone, without first conducting qualitative surveys to ask how we are doing. - Outsourced CS staff are not provided with adequate backend access to solve customer cases and are merely there to repeat what is already on our FAQ pages. Often, when they escalate cases to full time staff, it's regarding angry customers who had an issue that could have been solved quickly if a full time staff had attended to the case immediately. On several occasions, we've even been asked to help attend to the outsourced staff's inbox directly because they are overwhelmed. Doesn't this defeat the purpose of hiring outsourced staff, who are there to alleviate the full time staff's load?

Reviews.Pros: incredible culture and wonderful team members.

Reviews.Header: Amazing benefits, great culture, lots of learning and growth
Reviews.Pros: - Higher base salary vs other companies + RSUs - Amazing benefits (22 days Annual Leave + 3 Me Days), 6 week sabbatical at 4 year mark, weekly Buffets, monthly office events/celebrations - Travel opportunities - Strong Work Life Balance culture - Meaningful mission, and relatable company values

Reviews.Header: Good for learning experience, bad for promotional culture
Reviews.Pros: Access to learning is good and the experience gained while at Wise was valuable because we take on much more than what is required and you have some freedom to focus on what you wish to learn.
Reviews.Cons: Internal job promotions or interviews for higher positions are fake. Most of the time the interviews are just done as a formality when they already have someone they want in mind. There are also times when a internal role was given to someone without a formal interview or sufficient backing. Promotions here are not based on work but based on relationships. The phrase here "fake it till you make it" is apt. There is also a disproportionate amount of female leads within the company. There's also a lot of fluff culture within the leads that just pat each other's back for a good job without considering how their team members feel or addressing our concern.

Reviews.Header: Great for people who loves ownership
Reviews.Pros: The engineering teams at Wise are empowered to make all sort of decision, they are always on the driver seat when it comes to product development and the roadmap. If you care about a cause/pain-point or whatsoever nobody can stop you from owning it and solving it (this is true even for non-engineering functions). Teams and people are very nice to work with and are respectful which makes collaborating a breeze. I think it's one of the best places for the people who want to own their career as you've complete autonomy over it.
Reviews.Cons: Autonomy comes with responsibilities, you might initially find it hard to see the lines between the ownership of different functions, essentially a side-effect of autonomous teams, but with enough time/practice it's not that hard to get hold of.

Reviews.Header: World class talent but has gone too fat to move fast
Reviews.Pros: - Working with world-class talent - Great culture - Many Stripes I met are the kindest people I ever know
Reviews.Cons: - Heavy emphasis on docs culture and process which contributes to moving slow - Development tooling can't keep up with the growth of headcount within tech org, it's hard to make simple changes

Reviews.Pros: - Pay is above average. - IPO possible in 2023 - Products are innovative - Great brand recognition globally.
Reviews.Cons: - Leadership team is toxic, creates a culture of fear among employees - Targets are not consistent among reps, based on favoritism and not when you join the organization - Reps are not collaborative and extremely competitive with each other - Not invested into culture at all, they are merely there for optics purposes - Middle management in regional offices sometimes have no experience in management. - Internal process are a joke, alot of the sales teams still use excel. - Extremely budget conscious with team building or general team outings. - Alot of the employees are arrogant and do not want their peers to succeed. - Constantly changing strategy on which markets to enter and pull out from - Overall disingenuous and fake vibes - No empathy for overall well being

Reviews.Pros: Great people that are all generally very supportive and genuinely interested in your ideas and success. Encouragement and positivity are pretty widespread.
Reviews.Cons: Promotion process is in my experience is extremely opaque and is mgr/mgr's mgr driven and your directly involvement/influence over it is negligible. Being in Singapore has directly held me back from promotion due to decision makers being located in the US. Prioritisation and decision making is probably the two biggest things holding Stripe back. Its difficult to prioritise as an IC because leaders don't give you a good idea or help on what should be prioritised. Because of this there's a seemingly endless number of projects people are spending (and often wasting) their time on because no one effectively tells people they need to not prioritise it. Its widespread and pervasive. Decision making its the weakest point. Simple decisions (i.e. decisions on things that have low risks and can very easily be undone) takes ages to decide on.

Reviews.Header: Great outlook for the company, weak trajectory for APAC

Reviews.Header: Poor leadership and lack of direction
Reviews.Pros: Some of the brightest and most empathetic people I've met are from Stripe.
Reviews.Cons: Poor leadership; The leadership team has no direction, and have changed the company focus multiple times within a year. For a company that prides itself on being transparent, management has restricted the amount of information that is shared with the ground staff. Massive overhiring in 2022 has led to much redundancy and the recent lay-offs in November 2022, yet in October 2022, management is still convincing everyone that the hiring is justified and outlook is strong. Completely do not recommend this company;

Career progression is also difficult.

Reviews.Header: Perfect place for workaholic looking for challenges
Reviews.Pros: -People are nice and smart here to work with -Business is thriving with solid product and reputation -Pay is on the upper side of the market with attractive RSU -Awesome transparency and documentation
Reviews.Cons: -You are expected to work until the bone, weekends work and nighttime calls are expected, definitely not a place to work if you want to have a work-life balance and you have a family, especially for Singapore. High tendency to burn out. -The processes are broken and always changing, since this role is developing, you are expected to wear A LOT of hats and to deliver A LOT of things in a short period of time, without a clear definition of who does what. It is a startup culture in enterprise organisation scale hence expect chaos. -Underinvested and limited career opportunities/development especially for a non-developer or technical role. -The reason people stay is because of RSU. Many people will join here to get the jump in salary and branding in CV for their next opportunity.

Reviews.Header: Middle Management have minimal experience and training.
Reviews.Pros: Great office environment Humble and friendly people all around Awesome medical and work/life benefits
Reviews.Cons: Ineffective and inexperience managers: I have seen many people managers promoted into their roles without any real training or prior experience at all. People management involves being responsible for the growth, wellbeing and career trajectories of actual human beings, Too many junior managers at Stripe simply given the role of managing a team without having any clue what they are supposed to do on a day to day basis. This results in ALOT of unnecessary attrition of otherwise good talent which I have personally witnessed. Not enough emphasis and importance placed on the growth of APAC offices, product localisation, new market launches, local pain points and talent development are often overlooked/deprioritised and severe lack of internal mobility that is otherwise seen in the US/EMEA offices.

Reviews.Pros: A good place to work for.
Reviews.Cons: A lot of thing changes everytime.

Reviews.Header: Overworked, very little diversity in eng org, but hopefully big pay off
Reviews.Pros: The work is very high impact and there are lots of opportunities to learn if you're not already familiar with the fintech space. Most of the big projects I've been on so far have been fun to work on. There are also a lot of talented, kind, and helpful engineers at Stripe who are really nice to learn from. I really enjoy my manager and the folks on my team. The money + bonuses are ~ok~. Pretty standard for a pre-IPO unicorn, but the goal is that there will be a big pay off later (fingers crossed).
Reviews.Cons: - The work life balance is *bad*. For how many products Stripe has, we are a very lean company. Too lean. There's just a lot of work, and very very tight deadlines, very fast paced, and not enough engineers and product managers to do all of it. If you want WLB as an engineer, join an infrastructure team, not a product team. - There is little to no investment in making the engineering org more diverse. This was surprising to me because of a lot of public facing company statements, but don't be fooled like I was. People (at least in the eng org) do not care about diversity. - HR sucks. And of course they would, I guess. But I had a really negative experience with HR where I walked away feeling completely devalued and gaslit. - Dev environments kinda suck and make the work a lot slower than it should be.

Reviews.Pros: The pay is good because otherwise they can't get people
Reviews.Cons: I decided to share my experience within the organisation. My time at Stripe is a place with an unhealthy culture. First, most people who work at Stripe hate it and verbally say that. However, Stripe pays a lot, and that is a reason for people to stay. I remember a recruiter telling me a Stripe is one of the best-paying companies. If another company pays more, they have a boring product or a terrible culture. Stripe has to spend a lot as well because the culture is toxic. There is a culture of selfishness, intimidation and creating fear to let people do what they want. I tried to contact HR to share my story in multiple situations, but they didn't want that. They point you to the virtual door. At this time, when you experience inappropriate behaviour, HR should listen to you; however, in my case, that did not happen. I understand that money is, to most people, a big driver, but Stripe is not worth it. They have a high turnover rate, and this is because of the culture in the organisation. I know many people who started working after I left the organisation, and they all say it was one of there worst experiences in their working career.

Reviews.Header: Worst company in my life; they treat you like robots who only care about money
Reviews.Pros: The pay is good. Their equity is finally worth something.
Reviews.Cons: Senior management does not seem to know that their employees are humans, not robots. In this company and on my team, there's hardly any team activity, chit-chat, social activity, team building, lunch/dinner, etc. Most teams in the company are distributed but managers are not trained nor capable of managing remote employees. Hence, people in this company don't talk to each other casually that much. They are like work robots who only communicate for work. Slack is work and work only. The company doesn't invest in any social activities like Christmas party. I am not saying that I love corporate events. But there is zero... Hence, people just turn on their company at 9am, work on their laptop and never talk to each other like humans do. Employees have very weak personal relationships with each other. It's soul crushing. The only thing they offer is equity, which is a golden handcuff. They don't offer you cash raises that much during performance reviews. If you perform well, you get these equity grants in March which only start vesting quarterly from August (5 months later). That's their way to trap you in this awful environment for longer. The CEO loves Amazon. I suppose that's why they created this Amazon-like fear-driven environment. People are afraid to speak up. They don't dare to challenge their boss. They do whatever their boss says, until all of a sudden, their bosses are let go without notice. They actively manage people out even though sometimes our systems, onboarding and environment didn't allow employees to succeed. Employees are just let go without notice. You will often here "today is XXX's last day / last Friday was their last day". It's like a zombie movie. In employee survey, lots of people indicate that they don't want to stay in the company for more than 1-2 years and they don't feel like there is any career growth. But management never addressed them or tried to do anything to change it. When they talk about "culture", it's about "productivity and efficiency". Stripe only hires people who've been doing a similar job for many years. Therefore, people can't easily move internally to try something different. Leadership doesn't invest in or sponsor any DEIB activities. A lot of employees are not happy that they did a private equity raise instead of IPO, which would have likely set us at a higher valuation. If you're a productive and soulless robot who loves being tied to a golden handcuff while working on a payment software seeing your coworkers disappear randomly, this is the place for you to work.

Reviews.Header: Great company, great benefits, good company culture
Reviews.Pros: This was my first job after college. I had the best manager and really good team. Competition is in the nature of a sales role but still we were a strong team. Realistic targets. Everyone is always open to help and there was a 1 month long training when I first started. Afterwards, when I wasn't performing great they offered to give me another 1 month training instead of firing me. They definitely don't hire people to fire.
Reviews.Cons: Nothing bad to say. This was a great experience. Sales was not for me.

Reviews.Header: Fast paced, lots to learn but as expected
Reviews.Pros: Salary - The pay is really good and stacks up well against the market. People - Stripe hires smart, competent people, often from different background from what you might typically find in the tech world. Food - It baffles me that some reviewers put this in the con section. It's free food. Honestly, what do some people think they are owed? Management - My direct line manager is great and anyone I have encountered has also been very competent. No complaints here. Vision - The Collison bros are obviously extremely smart individuals with a great vision for the product. I feel comfortable with them at the helm.
Reviews.Cons: Career Progression - No clear pathway for new starters to get promoted. People who join Stripe often stay here for a while, probably waiting for the IPO pay day. This means in periods of slow growth, like the one we are currently in, it can be difficult to see where the next step forward is. Messy Processes - Stripe has grown so fast that they have struggled to bring their processes up to speed in tandem. It can be difficult to get easy things done. Thankfully, they are aware of the issue and are attempting to resolve it. Overworked - Can't speak to this from a personal viewpoint but I do get the feeling that Stripe is understaffed and overworked in many key departments which is causing a lot of stress.

Reviews.Pros: - Smart/Intelligent people - Innovative/Creative - Pushes employees to work smart and elevate work ethic - Kind and thoughtful people - Culture encourages empathy - Close to IPO - Brand name company - Thoughtful layoff approach - Thoughtful communication style
Reviews.Cons: - Chaotic - SUPER POLITICAL - No work-life blend - A lot of management should be managed out - Clique-y - Perf/talent review process is unreasonable - Poor recognition - Hustle culture - Lack of employee appreciation - Everyone is really burnt out

Reviews.Header: There was opportunity until there wasn't
Reviews.Pros: Good people to work with, employee perks are often good too. Steep initial learning curve about payments and fintech which was good when starting.
Reviews.Cons: No progression opportunities from SDR - not looking like this will change anytime soon given the current economy Poor management and communication - numerous attempts to pull the wool over SDR eyes by promising things (e.g. promotion in a year), not delivering and then changing the narrative (you can promote in 18-24 months). Sales education is subpar - team mostly gets by because the power of Stripe brand in the market. Spray and pray emailing is common. Targets keep increasing as opposed to reflecting the economic environment around us. Pay varies wildly with the more senior and longer running SDRs actually earning MUCH LESS than the newer hires - I've heard of one SDR earning around 60k OTE and another 75k (the pay difference for the same work is disgusting)

Reviews.Pros: good food good people smart people
Reviews.Cons: lots of work too much work

Reviews.Pros: The benefits, perks and compensation were outstanding and well above average.
Reviews.Cons: My direct team were supportive and like family anything outside of that we/the "diverse" were treated like outsiders --there was little to no "inclusion".

Reviews.Pros: Hard-working, kind colleagues; successful and valuable product; lots of learning on the job
Reviews.Cons: Leadership makes decisions without fully considering the employee experience, tons of thrash, no real commitment to DEI or internal pay equity, founders are brilliant but have major blind spots when it comes to creating a culture of trust and safety - have given this topic lip service but done nothing to change it; burnout culture.

Reviews.Pros: -Excellent pay -Many other people who work there are nice and trying desperately to look out for one another
Reviews.Cons: -Every decision made at Stripe is done so in a desperate, terrified bid to avoid the CEO's disapproval. That is it. That is the sole cultural center of Stripe. -Individualist, often offensive, seemingly misogynistic CEO surrounded by "yes" people with not a single soul in leadership willing to call him out. -Messy messy messy. Internal processes, internal communications, internal organization, policies, procedures, etc. either don't exist or are impossible to track down and understand. A shiny exterior, but inside the employee experience is nearly impossible to navigate. -There is one specific type of worker who can thrive at Stripe. And if you have any cares in the world outside of looking like a producer at work (read: family, hobbies, children, morals, etc.), you don't fit the bill, and you will feel bad every day.

Reviews.Pros: Pay, work flexibility (location, hours), training and onboarding is amazing, mac environment, health insurance is really good, monthly wellness stipend was good.
Reviews.Cons: I was at Stripe (I made a career change) for less than a year before I was laid off, so it's difficult to find another similar role with little experience. It seems as if company culture can be immature, I've had coworkers randomly let go without warning, prior to layoffs.

Reviews.Header: Solid teammates, but expect to work weekends
Reviews.Pros: -Eng team was extremely impressive and took on a lot of ownership including writing PRDs -very data driven, lots of analyses -People in general were very sharp
Reviews.Cons: -WLB: even though my manager told me working weekends wasn't expected, many people did which felt like it was expected -product intuition driven culture vs. experiments driven -product team lacked resources and wasn't clear when hires would happen

Reviews.Pros: High potential for growth Cool projects to work on Leader in its field Great (in-office) perks Great brand name to get on your resume
Reviews.Cons: Sales people are treated as the second class citizens of Stripe: - A special equity bonus program was rolled out to the whole company except sales people. Why? We just heard it's "too complicated" to set this up for sales people who are on variable commissions. - You don't get paid on new products you sell. Stripe launches new products all the time. Even though you're expected to learn, promote, and sell these products, you won't get paid until the comp team gets around to figuring this out which could take 6 months or longer. - Very little support offered to closers. AEs are expected to do a lot of their own prospecting. The outbound org is still very undeveloped. - Same goes for post-signed support. No clean breaks. Even if you attach a support package to your deal, you'll find yourself continuing to work with that company well after you close the deal. - You spend less time selling and more time working in tickets given the complexity of deals at Stripe. - Really bad sales incentives compared to other high growth sales organizations. Lengthy commission cycles that lack transparency, little to no spiffs (the few I've seen are paltry), although we did just get accelerators! Hell will freeze over before Stripe offers a Prez Club. The equity bonus program mentioned above was the biggest slap in the face.

Reviews.Pros: - compensation is ok but coming down
Reviews.Cons: - work nonstop including weekends - too much reporting including what you did each day - cost cutting. Growth is gone.
